DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF SIR ROBERT HELPMANN, CBE

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on 28 September 1986, of Sir Robert Murray Helpmann, CBE.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on 28 September 1986, of Sir Robert Murray Helpmann, CBE, dancer, actor, choreographer, director and producer, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious service to the Australian Ballet and tenders its profound sympathy to the members of his family in their bereavement.

It is only in exceptional circumstances that motions of condolence are moved for distinguished Australians who have not sat in the Parliament. I think that the last occasion was on the death of Sir Macfarlane Burnet. It is appropriate today that we commemorate the outstanding career of Sir Robert Helpmann. Sir Robert was a distinguished Australian. His career as a dancer, choreographer, stage, film and theatre actor and director was one of the richest, liveliest and most productive in Australia's cultural life. Sir Robert Helpmann was born at Mount Gambier on 9 April 1909. He started ballet classes at a young age and went on to achieve fame in Europe and America. His singular talent was recognised and applauded not only by his audiences but also by his peers. There is not sufficient time here to list his achievements individually. There were many successes, particularly in his efforts to produce new and exciting dance work.

I remind honourable senators that Sir Robert Helpmann left Australia in 1932 at a time when opportunities to develop his art and his craft were limited. In 1955 he returned to Australia as an actor to appear in three Shakespearean plays with the American actress, Katharine Hepburn. With Peggy van Praagh he became joint artistic director of the Australian Ballet Company in 1964. While his associations with ballet in Australia were not without controversy and disappointment, his was a major influence in the development of ballet and theatre in this country. He made significant creative contributions also to our film, television, and, on one occasion, even our pop music industries. In 1964 he received the honour of Commander of the British Empire, and other honours were bestowed on him at later stages of his life. Sir Robert had an extraordinary theatrical career. He leaves to Australians the richness of his imagination and strong sense of the dramatic, as demonstrated in his choreography. Australia's cultural life has broadened and we have produced more playwrights, painters and directors of international standing and repute, but no one can underestimate Sir Robert Helpmann's role in the development of the growing maturity of Australia's art and culture.

Sir Robert Helpmann brought great joy and satisfaction to the millions who saw his work. His great talent will live on in his films and his choreography. It will also live on through the inspiration such a brilliant career offers to those Australian artists who will follow him. On behalf of the Government and all Australians I extend to his family our condolences in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I wish to support the motion of condolence moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and the comments he has made in support of that motion. I do not wish to say very much; Senator Collard, the spokesman for the Opposition on matters to do with the arts, will speak on this motion on its behalf and on behalf of the National Party of Australia. However, I do want to pay personal tribute to the career of an Australian which managed to span a number of different art forms. Sir Robert Helpmann was distinguished as a dancer, a choreographer, an actor and a producer. I think he was distinguished also in his confidence in the worth of his own contribution to those various fields and in the courage he showed in being himself. Of the many things which have been written since he died and which I have read, I think the point which struck me most was something written in the following terms in the Sydney Morning Herald:

SPEECH.PARA: Unlike most of his adversaries, his weapons were a rapier wit and a refusal to be subsumed by conventional thinking and its hidden inhibitions and fears. His nose-thumbing and courage was a priceless beacon for any boy or girl with an inkling that there might be more to life than plodding conformity.

I think they were very appropriate words to say of an Australian who made a very distinctive as well as distinguished contribution. I join with the Leader of the Government in the Senate in deeply regretting Sir Robert's death but in being very grateful for the contribution he made both to Australia and to the rest of the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). It was in an era when macho men did not pursue careers on the stage that the late Sir Robert Helpmann was born. He was often referred to as Bobby in his earlier years. He showed a natural talent for dance and took to the stage as early as eight years of age. His mother, as he said on many occasions, fostered and encouraged him while his father, a stock and station agent, regarded the stage and all its trappings as a waste of time. He was most outspoken in his views on this, although I understand that later on he did not stand in Sir Robert's way or criticise him. None of this deterred Sir Robert. He persevered. His mother encouraged his interest in areas other than dance with Shakespeare and the theatre. His interest was always the theatre, with ballet as a top priority.

SPEECH.PARA: It must be acknowledged that he showed a lot of courage and determination in those years. It would have been far easier for a young man in the 1920s and 1930s to become a miner, a shearer or a jackaroo than to aspire to the stage, let alone to be a ballet dancer. His great opportunity came when he was invited to go to England. His grandfather agreed to pay the fare, so in 1933 he sailed from Australia to England. There he came under the influence of Ninette de Valois, who in her memoirs wrote of Sir Robert Helpmann:

On the credit side: Talented, enthusiastic, extremely intelligent, great facility and vitality, witty, cute as a monkey, quick as a squirrel, a sense of the theatre and his own possible achievements therein.
On the debit side: Academically technically weak, lacking in concentration; too fond of having a good time and too busy doing it.

In London he went on to the Sadler's Wells School where he was accepted immediately. It was not long before he became the Sadler's Wells leading male dancer. It was in this time that he met the great lady of the dance of the twentieth century, Dame Margot Fonteyn. He starred in many ballets with her, forming a dancing partnership which probably has not been exceeded in this century. His coaching under Anna Pavlova had paid off. It is said that Pavlova launched his career-and what a career it has been.

One of my first introductions to ballet was one that Sir Robert Helpmann has become famous for, the Display, which is all about the lyre bird in the bush. Interestingly, his interest in the lyre bird was regenerated when he came back to Australia on a trip with Katharine Hepburn, which was mentioned by Senator Button. They went into the bush with some of the cast and saw some of our native birds and wildlife. As an article in John Bull put it in 1946:
Ballet was invented in France, perfected in Russia, adopted in England and transformed by Helpmann.

Sir Robert Helpmann's stage performances could be likened to that of an all-round sportsman. He was successful in many spheres. As Senator Button said, he was a dancer, choreographer, actor, and director. He was a great artist. He even sang at Covent Garden in a ballet. At 71 he recorded four surfing songs which startled the theatrical world. In an art form characterised by short careers, Sir Robert's was unique, although he recognised that any dancer has a reasonably short career. After he switched to the Old Vic and became an actor he said that in his youth he remembered everybody saying: `Oh, Pavlova is finished, and she is only 42'. It had quite a salutary effect on him, and so he did branch out. Nevertheless, he was still dancing at 77, weeks before he went into hospital. He was still on the stage. That was in a role that had been created for him 50 years before. He was playing the Red King in Checkmate. This was half a century after he had thrilled European audiences with his performance. His recreated role, the Red King, was more an acting role than a dancing role. The drama side of dance always interested him more.

It would not be right to pay tribute to this great master without mentioning his outrageous style. A tale often told about him was when he was dunked in the Bondi surf by a group of lifesavers who objected to his painted nails, plucked eyebrows, pink shirt and purple tie. Nonetheless, he revelled in the controversy he created. His trademark was his style of dress, adorned with heavy gold jewellery. Sir Robert never forsook his country. His 20 years plus absences in England where the English took him as their own did not weaken his ties with his birthplace. He always regarded himself as an Australian, although much of his life was spent away from these shores.

Earlier this year he cut his ties with England for all time when he sold his flat. During a sojourn overseas Sir Robert not only learned but also started putting his own touches to ballets and performances. His contribution to the advancement and development of dance both overseas and here was unparalleled, particularly the encouragement he gave to younger dancers and actors in Australia. This has become legend. His love of the theatre and his ability to use it as a medium of communication and expression knew no bounds. He put this country on the map in the cultural arena. He was truly Australia's greatest ambassador for the arts. His loss will be felt in the theatre world in Australia. He was always looking for new challenges and was never content to rely on past successes. Most importantly, he had fulfilled his mother's dream. I suppose his attitude to the theatre could be well summed up by what he told his authorised biographer:

Theatre remains the only thing I understand . . . It is in the community of the theatre that I have my being. In spite of jealousies and fears, emotional conflicts and human tensions; in spite of the penalty of success and the dread of failure; in spite of tears and feverish gaiety, this is the only life I know. It is a life of love.
That sums up his attitude to the theatre. Today, here in the Senate, we pay a compliment to a man who put Australia on the world stage. He was one of our great ambassadors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate the Australian Democrats with this motion of condolence regarding Sir Robert Helpmann. His death brings to an end a career remarkable in many ways. The stories which have been published about him are numerous. It can be said safely that very few people have been so successful over such a long period. His theatrical flair brought a unique, indefinable quality to the type of work that he did in so many areas of the arts. Despite his genius and his characteristic flamboyance, Sir Robert was renowned for not being too haughty to talk to even his humblest fan. His numerous successes in the theatre showed that his very astute judgment of what the public were looking for at any particular time did not fail him. Even at the age of 77 he still had what it took to get up on stage before a full house, give his all and create the theatrical magic that was so important to the economic success of what he managed to do throughout life.

SPEECH.PARA: During a period when Australia suffered from its perennial cultural cringe Sir Robert did as much as he could to reverse that. Unfortunately, the cultural cringe lives on. Sir Robert gave inspiration to many others to see Australia as a place from where one could start, and astound the world. We have a lot to offer in this country. Not all good things necessarily come from overseas. It was particularly pleasing to Sir Robert's many fans that he finally came home and that on his death he was still actively participating in his beloved theatre. He said on many occasions that the principal purpose of the theatre was to entertain-and that he did remarkably well. He will be deeply missed by many, but his long life does not leave one so much with regret, but with admiration for so much that he did and for the enormous contribution he made, which will certainly live on after him.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Military and Intelligence Facilities in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains electronic communication facilities, operated by Australian and American personnel, that gives the United States the ability to pin-point Soviet nuclear submarines, hidden in the oceans.

2. This would make it possible for U.S. killer-submarines to destroy all Soviet nuclear submarines, while the U.S. nuclear submarines launch their missiles in a `first strike' attack. This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disastrous effect on Melbourne.
3. The `joint U.S.-Australian' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should close the `joint Australian-U.S.' electronic communication facilities in the Watsonia Army Barracks.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows: That we urge you to oppose the Australian Bill of Rights Bill because:
We get no legally enforceable rights under the Bill.

The Bill does not guarantee vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property and not be deprived of it without just compensation and the right of choice between government and non-government schools.
The Bill gives Canberra extra powers to change our Federal system by the back door without a constitutional referendum.
The Bill gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should vote against the Bill of Rights, support Opposition amendments and seek a genuine public debate and a referendum on the Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Rifle Range, Malabar, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That over 67,000 men, women and students enjoy the pursuit of their sport and recreation every year at the Anzac Rifle Range at Malabar and have done so since 1967.

2. The people of Sydney through their membership of 41 clubs headquartered at the Anzac Rifle Range together with a number of other community, school and commercial groups, the police and armed forces will lose this community facility if the Federal Government proceeds to sell the Range to private developers.
3. The Australian Bicentenary Fullbore Rifle Championships are to be conducted at the Anzac Rifle Range in April 1988 as part of the celebration of Australia's Bicentenary.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should ask the Federal Government to retain the Anzac Rifle Range for the continued use and enjoyment of the people of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your House eliminates this outrageous and unjust castigation of our population which is leading to the downfall of this country.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to his comments last week about the horrifying paper work associated with the Government's package of taxation measures-paper work which is too difficult for the Minister to understand-and similar concerns expressed by the Prime Minister, three Labor State Premiers, the Federal Secretary of the Australian Labor Party and the Leader and Deputy Leader of the Opposition in Queensland, as well as the Opposition and hundreds of thousands of individual Australians. I ask: What has the Minister done and, if he has done nothing, what will he do to reduce the crazy paper work burden imposed on business by the fringe benefits tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly there have been representations made to the Government in respect of the fringe benefits tax by various people to whom Senator Chaney referred. Some of those representations have been made by people who do not want a fringe benefits tax at all and some have been made by people who express concern about alleged complexities in the tax. I was lucky enough to have advance notice of this question because the Leader of the Opposition put out a Press release about it last week in which he said this:

ANSWER.PARA: But this time, Senator Button will not be allowed to go to water.
By the end of next week, he must be called on to answer three questions:
Has he talked to the Treasurer?
Has he forced the Government to get rid of the administrative nightmare? or
Has he again let down small business people?

The answer to each of those questions is no. I have not talked to the Treasurer, who is overseas. I recently announced that. There have been no changes to the administrative arrangements for the fringe benefits tax and we have not let down small business people. I want to make this point in general regarding the fringe benefits tax: There have been some quite deliberate efforts to confuse the principle of the fringe benefits tax and some issues associated with the complexities of the administration of that tax. I will try to speak in words of one syllable so that Senator Boswell, who is trying to interject, can understand me, but words of one syllable may not be available to me because I want to try to identify the distinction between those two things. The principle of the fringe benefits tax was very clearly stated on 11 July 1980 in these words:

Fairness demands that employees who are paid solely in cash-and most Australians are-should not be asked to pay more tax and thus effectively subsidise those whose income is obtained partly in cash and partly in the form of valuable benefits of other kinds.

That principle was established by Mr John Howard when he was the Treasurer of this country and in a unique position to do something about the taxation system, including reducing marginal rates for ordinary taxpayers-something he never did. The principle enunciated by Mr Howard in 1980 was firmly supported last week by the Deputy Leader of the National Party, Mr Ralph Hunt, when, apparently in some confusion, he said that Mr Howard had made it clear that he was not going to allow the fringe benefits issue as such to be a tax avoid- ance device. Mr Hunt continued:

In other words, he is not going to allow company executives to have half their salary paid by kind without tax, such as providing a house, interest-free loans and a Mercedes-Benz car and free education for their children . . . That is obviously a tax-avoidance scheme.

Mr Hunt understands the principle of a fringe benefits tax, as did Mr Howard in 1980, but at lunch time today the Leader of the sansculotte Opposition we have here, this rag and bobtail Opposition, had this to say--

TALK.START.PARA: —Bring out the tumbrels.

—No, I will not bring out the tumbrels for Mr Howard; members of the Opposition will in time, not me. Just let me say that on this issue today, the man who established the principle in 1980, which was confirmed by the Deputy Leader of the National Party last week, had this to say: `The principle of the tax is wrong and so is the administration'. That is what John Howard, Leader of the Opposition, said at ten past twelve today. That is what he has had to say. It is very important to distinguish between the principles of the fringe benefits tax, widely accepted as it is in the Australian community, and some administrative complexities which may exist. —Has the Minister for Community Services seen the claims made in the Tasmanian Press by Senator Walters that $33m has been used so far on advertising in the national drug offensive? Is this true? Are any other claims made by Senator Walters about the national drug offensive true?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Devlin for his question. I did see the articles in both the Hobart Mercury and the Launceston Examiner quoting Senator Walters as a member of the coalition's drugs task force committee. She did say apparently, according to the journalists in both newspapers, that the Government appropriated $100m to use over three years of the campaign and the $30m used so far this year has been largely spent on advertising. Senator Walters is wrong as usual. She could not be more wrong. The public information advertising allocation for the drugs campaign over the next three years totals $5m in each of the 3 years out of a budget of $100m, not the $30m that Senator Walters claims has been spent this year. The thing that fascinates me is that Senator Walters and the Opposition should know that this is a national campaign. It is a campaign run in co-operation with the State governments-a Liberal Government in Tasmania, a National Party Government in Queensland, a Country Liberal Party strange Government in the Northern Territory and the Labor governments of the other States. They are working in the program in co-operation. Senator Walters, in attacking the program in the way she does, is clearly attacking all those governments and particularly her beloved Mr Gray, and Mr Roger Groom, who is the Minister for Health in Tasmania.
—You obviously haven't read the statement.

—I have read the statement and the newspaper articles. I suppose Senator Walters will tell us that both journalists who wrote the articles in Tasmania have misquoted what she obviously said. No one believes that that is not so. But Senator Walters said other things that are not true. For instance, she claimed that only six of the 71 agencies and projects surveyed-I remind honourable senators that the survey was done in New South Wales only-have received funds from the campaign. In fact, 55 of the 71 agencies named in the survey quoted by Senator Walters have received funds. The Opposition's task force claimed, in its survey, that Pallister received nothing from the joint funding arrangements. In fact, Pallister, the primary prevention and health education agency, received $393,000. Senator Walters claimed that We Help Ourselves received nothing when, in fact, it received $104,000. She claimed that GROW received nothing. In fact, it claimed $33,000. The task force claimed that only the New South Wales Government contributed to the cost of life education mobile vans, whereas both the State and Federal governments provided $782,000 under the campaign. The list continues. I suppose that Senator Walters would say that some of the organisations would not know that they receive Federal funds. All members of the committee of which Senator Walters is a member should know that.

ANSWER.PARA: The national campaign is based on a strategy agreed to by the States and the Commonwealth. It is based on a strategy which was largely put forward in a report called `Drug Problems in Australia-An Intoxicated Society' written by a committee of which Senator Peter Baume, Senator Walters and I were members. I wish that she and members of her committee would go away and read the report. She is denigrating a campaign in which all State governments and the Federal Government are co-operating. They are trying to do something about a problem which we all accept is a difficult problem in Australia. We will do much better-Liberal, National Party and Labor State and Federal governments-without the carping nitpicking of people such as Senator Walters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce concerned about the serious slump in the car industry, with an expected drop of at least 150,000 sales this year compared with last year? What action, if any, has the Minister taken or will he take to alleviate the economic and social impact of the slump? Does he agree that the most obvious helpful single action the Government could take would be to remove the fringe benefits tax, action which, based on industry estimates, would boost sales by at least 50,000 units?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course I am concerned about the downturn in production in the motor vehicle industry or, I should say, registration and sales in the motor vehicle industry, because the downturn in production is not as marked as the registration and sales figures suggest. We have had discussions about that matter in the Senate before. As I have pointed out, 1985 was a record year. It was anticipated, for a variety of reasons, that there would be a reduction in motor vehicle sales and registrations in 1986. That has been exacerbated by a downturn in the economy which has been apparent in the first two quarters of this year. It is not surprising that that effect followed. I am happy to be able to tell the honourable senator that, as far as I understand it, the August sales and registration figures for motor vehicles in industry terms suggest a bottoming out of the decline in motor vehicle sales. That is what the industry has said. It has also been reported to me that the figures for September show some slight improvement on what was anticipated. So while one cannot attach too much importance to that I think it is now the general industry view that the situation is a little better than it was and what it was anticipated to be.

ANSWER.PARA: The point of the question is whether the fringe benefits tax has had an effect on the downturn in the motor vehicle industry. If it has, it has not demonstrated itself in the way one might have expected in view of the debate which took place about the fringe benefits tax on motor vehicles last year and early this year. The decline in sales of fleet motor vehicles-that is, fleets bought by companies and other organisations-has been less marked than the general reduction in sales of private cars. That certainly suggests that the fringe benefits tax, which it was argued would be the cause of a dramatic drop in fleet sales of motor cars, would have that effect and that it would be the principal effect on any decline in activity in the industry. The figures do not confirm that suggestion, which was made last year. I think it is very difficult to identify any one of a number of factors as being responsible for the general decline in motor vehicle industry sales and registrations. I think it is sufficient to say that a number of factors have been at work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Communications aware that Mr John Stone, formerly the Secretary to the Treasury and currently a relatively unread newspaper columnist, is reported as being a speaker at last Tuesday's meeting of the New Right H. R. Nicholls Society and that he accused the Australian Broadcasting Corporation of being a party to `a public misinformation campaign'? Is it the intention of the Government to take any action in response to this accusation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not only aware of this accusation but I personally heard Mr Stone on, I think, AM last Wednesday making this complaint, which was directed at the ABC and at Gillies Republic in particular. I will not read all of what he said, but he referred to the public misinformation campaign and complained that members of the H. R. Nicholls Society had been likened by Gillies to the South African bruderbond. I can only assume that Mr Stone has not seen the film Cabaret or he would have known that Gillies Republic was likening members of the H. R. Nicholls Society-or the ratbag Right rather than the H. R. Nicholls Society-not to the bruderbond but to the National Socialist Workers Party of the Weimar Republic. In fact, Tomorrow Belongs to Me, which was sung in parody by the assorted members of the ratbag Right at the end of the show, was virtually a nazi hymn.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that there is some legal action by one of the members of the ratbag Right. He is one of the trio who sponsors advertisements soliciting donations to run a political campaign against the fringe benefits tax. If people are going to pose as fascists they should not be surprised if they are described as fascists. I think Oscar Wilde found out about 100 years ago about posing as someone and then not being surprised that he was regarded as such. Finally, the extreme sensitivity of the members of the ratbag Right on this issue, I note for the record, is not--

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. The Minister has drawn attention to the fact that an individual has commenced proceedings alleging defamation very much on the basis of the sorts of comments which are being made in this place by the Minister, who, of course, is secure from similar writs because of privilege which does not provide any protection for the citizen. Since a writ has been issued, it seems to me that the matter clearly will come before the courts. I regard it as being very improper of the Minister to put the view which he is putting. In a sense, it buttresses the claim of slander and defamation which has been made. In other words, having drawn attention to the fact that legal proceedings have been commenced on the basis of the points that the Minister is making, it seems to me to be highly improper for him to go on dealing with the matter in the way that he is.

—At this stage there is no point of order. As I understand it, it has been the common practice over many years on the rule of sub judice for the rule not to apply until proceedings have commenced in any court. Therefore, in that respect the rule does not apply. However, I ask the Minister to bear in mind when making comments that, I understand from what the Minister has said, a writ has been issued. I also ask the Minister to answer the question specifically and not engage in any debate on the subject.

—Certainly, Mr President. I was just about to conclude. I was asked what the Government will do about this matter. I do not think that the Government will do anything about it but I will pass the question on to Mr Duffy, who is the Minister primarily responsible in this area. I believe that the extreme sensitivity of the ratbag Right when subject to satirical sending-up is not at all consistent with the language used by prominent members of the ratbag Right. I draw particular attention to the reference to declarations of civil war and storm-troopers at work destroying the economic and moral fabric of the nation, which was the language used by Charles Copeman in his speech to the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party on 1 September.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. When the Government announced the liberalisation of coal export regulations the Prime Minister explained the move as one designed to speed up the process of `internationalising the Australian economy'. Given Press speculation that coal exporters are now looking at price reductions of the order of $4 per tonne, would the Australian people be right in concluding that by `internationalising our economy' the Prime Minister means allowing us to be dominated by foreign interests?

—I am not sure of the point of the question. Nor am I aware-although I do not say that it is not necessarily so-of reports that Australian coal exporters are facing price reductions of $4 a tonne. Even if there are such reports and even if they are true that does not necessarily establish any particular cause of that outcome. Principally, I am astounded by the question-or mystified by it-and the apparently derogatory reference to internationalisation. I do not know what Senator Siddons wants-whether he wants an autarky and wants Australia to quarantine itself from the rest of the world. If that is his policy and that of the Australian Democrats, I can say only that it is certainly not the policy of the Government.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Education been drawn to a campaign of letters to the editor, these letters being used as a means of attack on the policy of having an administration charge for tertiary students? Further, these letters claim that the fee of $250 where it is reimbursed to needy students on Austudy or students on postgraduate awards will be the subject of tax resulting in a net cost to the student. Could the Minister outline the true position on the administration charge for tertiary students and provide any other details on the application of a tax to these fees?

—I have noticed the campaign of letter writing to various newspapers complaining about the administration charge. Unfortunately it is the case that many of those letters have contained errors of fact. In particular there have been letters from representatives of the Council of Australian Postgraduate Associations claiming that where the $250 is payable by post-graduate students and is subsequently reimbursed, along with payments from the Department of Education, that $250 will be counted as taxable income. I would like to state very clearly that that is not the case but that the $250 will be tax neutral because it is a reimbursement to the student for the charge. I think it is unfortunate that student associations or other alleged representatives of students make these errors of fact when making public statements.
—Did you have a good day at Sydney University last week?

—I would like to make it quite clear that the $250 will not be subjected to tax. Senator Peter Baume has interjected some reference to Sydney University. Again there is another example where some representatives of students, complaining about the administration charge, put to me the view that it would fall on the poorest students. When I pointed out to them that the charge would not affect anyone in receipt of any tertiary education assistance scheme payments, that it would not affect single parent beneficiaries, similar pensioner beneficiaries or Aboriginal students, they were quite surprised and subsequently had to change their line. So I think it is very important that all honourable senators in this place do not encourage any of these students in their misapprehensions about the charge. The $250, when reimbursed to students, will be tax free.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is he aware that no calculations as to the cost impact on the private sector of administering the fringe benefits tax were done before the details of the fringe benefits tax were worked out, nor were such calculations done in respect of the public sector? Given the Minister's recent expression of concern about the crazy new burden on business caused by the tax, why was it brought in without proper consideration of the costs of administration?

—I will address that question to the Treasurer and seek to obtain an early answer. Let me say, by way of speculation, that the measuring of the cost impact on the private sector I suspect would be an enormously difficult exercise. That there is a cost impact there I do not think would be disputed by anybody, but the measuring of it would be an enormous exercise.

—Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware of a report in today's Sydney Daily Telegraph that a war widow cannot be paid $20,500 awarded by the Veterans' Review Board? Is the report correct in stating that this stems from a defect in the new Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986? If so, what is being done to rectify the situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of the article in today's Sydney Daily Telegraph. I apologise to Mrs Doyle for the distress and delay that she has been caused as a result of changes made in the Veterans' Entitlements Act. When that Act was passed by the Parliament a number of sections in the old repatriation Acts dealing with payments which are now legally available to Mrs Doyle were repealed. A new section was inserted. The Veterans' Entitlements Act unfortunately has not realised the objectives of the legislation. Consequently there is a need for the Parliament to have a legislative basis for the payment of $20,000. It is not available to the Department of Veterans' Affairs at this time despite the fact that the award has been made by the Veterans' Review Board.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I can assure Senator Zakharov that we are aware of the difficulty, which was brought to our attention by the Attorney-General's Department on 6 August. An amendment has been prepared. My colleague Mr Howe will be proposing changes to the Social Security Act and the Veterans' Entitlements Act in the House of Representatives tomorrow. It will be debated in that House the following week and will then come to the Senate. We are anticipating the passage of the legislation in the Senate before this three-week sitting is finalised. Consequently we hope to make the payment, belated as it will be, to Mrs Doyle and overcome any embarrassment she has met in the circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does he recall talking to Playboy magazine last year about young people getting the dole or any other payment and saying: `In my view, if they want the allowance, they should work for it'? What has the Minister done, is he doing or will he do to implement that view?

—The interview was not last year; it was well before that. It must have been long in the gestation. The Government has examined a number of the issues associated with employment and unemployment benefit for young people. In the last Budget a new scheme was announced in respect of voluntary work by young unemployed people. That scheme is in the process of being implemented. It arose from a long series of discussions amongst relevant Ministers. We are very hopeful that that scheme will be of considerable benefit to those who take advantage of it, but that remains to be seen in the light of the working out of the scheme.
—I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister still subscribe to the view that young people should be engaged in study, training or some kind of work to receive the dole?
—Personally, I think that is desirable but there are enormous difficulties in arranging a society in which that takes place. I doubt whether there are any such societies.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Has his attention been drawn to an article on the front page of this morning's Canberra Times entitled `Opposition criticises two-tier wages plan'? If so, can the Minister indicate whether the Opposition's spokesperson on industrial relations, Mr Neil Brown, is correct in suggesting that indexation can only give more impetus to the wages tail chasing the prices dog and that a two-tier wage fixing process is completely inadequate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had my attention drawn to that article and to the reference to the wages tail chasing the prices dog. I thought Mr Brown would know more about cats than dogs. Leaving that aside, essentially what Mr Brown seems to be arguing against is the containment of wages outcomes, particularly the record that the accord has actually delivered. I gather that he wants to go back to the 1981-82 era when the Opposition had its last disastrous flirtation with a deregulated labour market and a wages explosion of 13 per cent in 1981 and 14 per cent in 1982 was produced. One would have thought that the Opposition would be reluctant to repeat that disastrous experiment or to argue that it should be repeated, not only because of its experience within Australia but also because of the experience of other countries which have not had the sort of wages agreement or consensus on wages outcomes which Australia has had since this Government has been in office or which a number of western and northern European democracies have had for a long time.

ANSWER.PARA: For example, let us look at the British situation. In spite of having a stridently anti-union Government and unemployment rates rising from above 10 per cent to above 13 per cent, British unions were able to win for their members real wage increases of 4.6 per cent, 3.6 per cent and 2.9 per cent in the calendar years 1983, 1984 and 1985 respectively. Over the same period, by the same measure, real wages in Australia fell by about 4 per cent. There is no precedent in Australian economic history for a decline in real wages during a period of high and sustained economic growth and falling unemployment. That is what the accord has delivered, a wages outcome which has never been delivered in Australia previously, a wages outcome which was necessary because of the wages explosion of 1981 and 1982 and also because of the recent deterioration in Australia's terms of trade, which has wiped about $6 billion off national income.

Some people might take the view that the outcome delivered by the accord is undesirable. That appears to be the view of Mr Crawford and the Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Union of Australia. I find it ironic, to say the least, that the policy of that union, which normally would be regarded by the Opposition as being of the extreme Left, is precisely the same as the policy that Mr Brown is trying to have adopted by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence and follows the sinking of a Soviet nuclear-powered and nuclear-armed submarine in the Atlantic Ocean following a fire on the ship. Is the Minister aware that nuclear submar- ines are in a different class from other nuclear-powered ships because of their size in that the reactor shielding is generally lighter and the entire installation more subject to faults because of the size and weight consideration? Is the Minister also aware that the uranium used in submar- ine reactors is generally more highly enriched-often virtually to bomb grade enrichment? In view of these factors and the fact that future sinkings of nuclear submarines might not necessarily be in remote parts of the Atlantic, will the Government now actively consider altering its policy to forbid entirely the entry of nuclear-powered submarines into Australian ports?

—I was asked whether I was aware of a number of alleged technical details about nuclear submarines. I am not aware whether the statements Senator Mason has made are correct and I will refer them to the Minister for Defence or somebody else who is competent to answer them; nor am I aware that the uranium used in submarine reactors is close to a weapons grade level of enrichment, and I would be surprised if that were so. I will have the matter checked out. As to the final part of the question, I think it unlikely that the Government's policy will be reconsidered. However, I will ask the Minister for Defence for his comment on that matter as well.

—Can the Minister for Education say whether Aboriginal bridging courses exist to help fill the gap for Aboriginal school leavers between current education and further study or opportunities in the work force? Are such courses available in all States? Do Aboriginals in rural areas have access to these resources?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government funds a number of programs to assist Aboriginals who leave school prior to year 12 or who are in other ways unprepared for further education and study. A number of courses funded through the technical and further education system are designed to prepare Aboriginal students to undertake trade courses or similar traineeships in the TAFE area. In higher education, that is, universities and colleges, there are courses known as enclave courses, specially funded by the Commonwealth, where Aboriginal students whose preparation for higher education is not adequate are given bridging and other sorts of tutorial and counselling assistance. As well as that, some new programs will be funded as a result of the Government's response to the report of the Miller Committee of Review of Aboriginal Employment and Training Programs. Details of those new projects were announced in the Budget.

ANSWER.PARA: As to whether the courses are available in all States, I believe that there are bridging courses available in TAFE colleges and enclave courses in colleges of advanced education and universities in all States. Although they are not available in every institution in all States, each State would have some institutions which offer those courses. In regard to whether those courses are available specifically in rural areas, again, I would think that most TAFE colleges which operate in rural areas where there is an Aboriginal population would have courses of these kinds, as would most CAEs. I will look further into this question and give Senator Elstob the details of actual institutions offering these courses.

I say in conclusion that although the Government does assist Aboriginals who leave school unprepared for further education or training in the ways I have set out, it is still of great concern to us that so few Aboriginal students are completing a full secondary education. Although the national figure for students who complete year 12 has moved up to 46 per cent of all students, the figure for Aboriginal students is only about 12 per cent-that is, only about 12 per cent of Aboriginal students finish a full secondary education. In terms of absolute numbers, that is very small. The Government, in consultation with the National Aboriginal Education Committee and other Aboriginal advisory bodies, is working on a strategy for improving participation rates by Aboriginal students. I hope that those strategies will have the full co-operation of honourable senators on both sides of the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to an article in Computing Australia of 29 September which quotes an Assistant Secretary of his Department as saying that there were white hats and black hats among computer companies tendering for an Australia Post contract, and, immediately following that statement, the naming of two black hat companies by so-called `sources'. Is it true that companies have been classified by the Department on the basis of their commitment to the offsets program? Does the Minister agree with the comments attributed to his Department, and does he support the making of such statements by public servants in his Department?

—I think I saw some oblique reference in a newspaper to the subject matter of Senator Sheil's question, but I am not in a position to answer the question in any detail. I will obtain an answer from the Department as soon as possible and provide it to him.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Defence seen Press reports in the Australian of Monday, 6 October, which stated that women may now apply for pilot training in the Royal Australian Air Force, and that up to four women will be selected in November, as announced by the Minister, Kim Beazley? In light of other comments in that article that women in the armed forces are creating problems, particularly in meeting combat readiness requirements, can the Minister say what percentage of workers in the armed forces are women and how that percentage has increased? Does he agree with Mr Sinclair, who is concerned `about the increasing use of women in the forces'? Does the Minister see the increase in the number of women as jeopardising the combat readiness of our armed forces, or is the increase being readily accepted by the forces?

—Senator Crowley asked what percentage of service personnel are female and what changes there have been in that percentage in recent years. I am afraid I cannot supply those details, but I am sure I can soon find them out from the Minister for Defence and let her know. I have seen the reports to which Senator Crowley referred. Indeed, I heard something about it on the wireless this morning. She asked whether I agreed with Mr Sinclair's view. I cannot imagine that I could agree with Mr Sinclair on anything, and I do not agree with him on this point, either.

—My question is directed to Senator Button in his capacity both as Leader of the Government in the Senate and as the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. The Minister would be aware that at least one month has now elapsed since he admitted that the Budget decision to reduce bounties by 20 per cent was not consistent with his industry policy decision. At the time I think he agreed to examine the matter. Do manufacturers who have lost this bounty have any prospects for relief?
—Which bounty?
—The 20 per cent.

—I am not clear on what the question is about, but I will answer it as best as I can and Senator Watson can work it out from there. First of all, let us be quite clear: I did say that the bounty cuts were made on fiscal policy grounds. We went through this at the Senate Estimates Committee and we have been through it at Question Time in the Senate. The Budget cuts were made on fiscal policy grounds, not on industry policy grounds, just the same as in the course of the administration of the Fraser Government over a number of years it made a lot of decisions on fiscal policy grounds-decisions which have been to the vast detriment of Australian industries since that time. Let us be clear about that.
—So is this one.

—Senator Watson begged the question. I do not have to answer the question if he knows that it is a detriment to all Australian industries that these bounty cuts were made. There is no prospect of the bounties-if he is referring to the textile bounties-being reviewed. There is no prospect of that, so he would be unwise to encourage the view that there is any prospect of that.
—Is there any relief?
—There is no prospect of review of that decision.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Is it a fact that the Government- owned Government Clothing Factory in the Prime Minister's electorate of Wills has recently been awarded a three-year contract to produce 148,500 disposable overalls for the Department of Defence? Is it also a fact that this contract was awarded to the Government Clothing Factory despite the fact that the factory has never made these garments previously and did not tender for the contract and that a private sector company which has been supplying the requirements of the Department of Defence in this area for many years did tender, and at prices considerably below those of the Government Clothing Factory? I ask the Minister: Who directed that this contract should go to the Government Clothing Factory, and what were the reasons for this direction?

—A lot of assertions were made in the question. I am not able either to confirm or refute those assertions. I was asked who directed that the contract go to the Government Clothing Factory. I do not know that at this stage. I will see whether I can find out. I do not know whether it was a ministerial decision or a departmental decision, but as I recall it has been the custom for a number of years and a principle accepted by a number of governments that there is a non-commercial reason for maintaining the Government Clothing Factory; that is, the policy is based on the assumption that should there be a war there would be substantial advantages in having that factory operating at the beginning of the war rather than at some time later. I believe that has been the case for a considerable period. If the facts are as Senator Short asserts them to be, that may well have been a factor in awarding this particular contract.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. The Minister will be aware of recent publicity in Western Australia given to the level of international air services to the State and also the potential for extra traffic generated because of the America's Cup challenge over the next few months. I ask: Will the Minister outline the Government's current view regarding the level of air services and any developments in the pipeline, particularly insofar as the America's Cup challenge is concerned? I ask that question mainly in relation to domestic air services rather than international air services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided me with a very adequate brief in respect of the way in which Western Australia is being served by international airlines. My brief indicates that currently 10 carriers operate scheduled services to Perth. In addition to that, Port Hedland is linked to Bali by a weekly flight. I understand further that Qantas Airways Ltd has reached agreement with several airlines in respect of new services from Perth. For example, Qantas and Japan Air Lines introduced from April this year a direct Perth-Tokyo once-weekly service.

ANSWER.PARA: I recall that another question was asked a couple of weeks ago about the America's Cup. The Government, of course, is well aware of the tourism likely to be generated by the defence of the America's Cup. It is giving sympathetic consideration to requests by airlines to operate additional capacity to cater for this extra demand which undoubtedly will create the need for extra services during the period of the America's Cup competition. Qantas, for its part, has already developed advanced capacity plans for that defence period, including two extra United States services via the Australian east coast and a weekly Perth-New Zealand service which, if it proves viable, could possibly continue after the challenge. I suppose one could say in response to Senator Coleman's question that the Aviation Minister is well aware of the demand that is likely to be generated as a result of the America's Cup event and that every step is being taken by the international airlines, including Qantas, to meet whatever demand is generated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Science seen the Budget briefing of the Bureau of Meteorology which states that in the financial year 1986-87 the Bureau will be forced to reduce its staff by 60? Is the Minister aware that earlier this year weather forecasters took the unprecedented step of issuing disclaimers with their forecasts because of staff shortages? Is the Minister aware that the Meteorology Policy Committee warned that without an injection of resources `a major breakdown in the Bureau's fragile warning infrastructure, with serious implications for life and limb, is a real possibility'? In view of these worrying developments and in view of the comments of the Director of the Bureau that the Bureau faced `major problems with staff shortages' and `serious workload difficulties', why did the Government, at ministerial direction, transfer four staff from the Bureau to the Commission for the Future?

—I am aware of many of the criticisms which were recited in Senator Archer's question. I am also aware of the fact that the Director of the Bureau of Meteorology somewhat qualified those criticisms at an Estimates committee meeting at which I was present and at which Senator Archer asked questions. The honourable senator might agree about that. His nod indicates that he does or, alternatively, that a degree of sleepiness may have come over him. I will direct to the Minister for Science the specific question of the transfer of staff from the Bureau of Meteorology to the Commission for the Future and obtain an early answer.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Finance been drawn to a front page article in the Sunday Territorian of 21 September 1986 titled `Shock Rail Plan Goes to Cabinet'? If so, can the Minister advise whether the proposals reportedly discussed by the Northern Territory Cabinet on Tuesday to fund a $160m start to the railway-specifically, a one-off grant from the Federal Government and the sale of mortgages on State housing commission homes to a bank-would be acceptable to the Commonwealth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the report published a couple of weeks ago to which Senator Cook refers. That report is the only information I have on this matter and that caveat should be lodged over the conclusion that one draws from it. It would appear that the proposal which has been put, or will be put, to the Territory Government is that the Government flog off about $160m worth of government owned housing to a private institution-in other words, capitalise or liquidate its asset by flogging off capital in order to provide a $160m interest free capital injection for this railway that it has been proposing for some time-or, alternatively, get a $160m grant from the Commonwealth to do it. It has no chance of doing that. I can tell the Northern Territory Government in advance that this Government will not waste $160m of taxpayers' money on that white elephant. The very fact that even the Territory Government admits that a $160m free capital grant is required establishes that the proposed investment, so-called, is not rational and is not responsible.

ANSWER.PARA: I must say I am surprised that Canadian Pacific Railway was willing to put its name to an analysis as shonky as the so-called analysis which was done for the territorial Government on a Darwin-Alice Springs railway. The analysis conducted by Canadian Pacific was shonky in a number of respects. Firstly, it assumed that all the traffic would be carried throughout the entire length of the railway, that nothing would be dropped off at Katherine or any other intermediate point. Secondly, it assumed that all the freight that moved from north to south would be carried on the railway and that none would be carried on the road. Thirdly, it took into account the alleged benefit to the rest of the railway system in Australia of the increased traffic that would be carried on the railway as far as Alice Springs and on the rest of the rail system to other parts. Those external benefits, to the degree that they exist at all, apply whether the traffic is moved from Darwin to Alice Springs by rail, road or any other means. Those other external benefits are there in any case. In other words, there are three quite specific points in which the analysis done by Canadian Pacific Railway was quite shonky. There is a fourth one I cannot remember off the top of my head. It does not surprise me that the territorial Government would promote a shonky analysis, but I am surprised that Canadian Pacific was willing to put its name to it.

Senator Cook asked whether the Commonwealth Government would be happy if the Northern Territory Government were to find the capital for this white elephant by flogging off its assets. I do not think the Commonwealth Government would be altogether happy about it, but the Commonwealth Government is not happy about many of the fiscally irresponsible actions which the Northern Territory Government has taken over a number of years, in particular in the period when the present Federal member for the Northern Territory was Chief Minister. We have been unhappy about many things that that Government has done. I and probably other members of the Commonwealth Government are concerned about the degree to which the territorial Government has underwritten private sector borrowings, or given government guarantees on private sector borrowings, for proposals the viability of which is yet to be demonstrated, to say the least, and ought to be seriously called into question.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FREMANTLE GAS AND COKE CO. LTD

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Finance, follows his last answer and his continued interest in the financial affairs of the Northern Territory and Queensland governments. I ask: Will he take the same approach to the Burke Government in Western Australia? In particular is he completely satisfied with the purchase of Fremantle Gas and Coke Co. Ltd and the involvement and role of the State Minister for Minerals and Energy, Mr Parker, in the approval of a bonus share issue in May prior to the sale of that company?

—I do not believe there is any need to take the same degree of interest in the financial affairs of the Western Australian Government as there is in those of the Queensland and Northern Territory governments. Whatever record previous Western Australian governments may have had, the present Western Australian Government does not have a record of fiscal irresponsibility, let alone of corruption. As far as I know, the Premier of Western Australia has not received a $400,000 out-of-court bogus libel settlement, as the Premier of Queensland has. Nor has the son of the Premier of Western Australia had a $5m dam built adjacent to his farm with taxpayers' money and fortuitously, just before this announcement was made, granted an 18-inch pumping licence from the billabong which was to be filled by that dam. To further emphasise the point which is being made, this proposition has never been on the Queensland State application list sent to the Commonwealth Government for funding. Nothing like that has happened in Western Australia and I do not believe anything like it ever will.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Ltd and the role of the State Government in those transactions? Since 1977 the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations has tabled a number of reports on the activities of Commonwealth statutory authorities and certain Commonwealth corporations. While undertaking inquiries into the activities of these bodies, the Committee was aware that the Parliament knew little of the activities of another large group of government bodies, the so-called non-statutory bodies, or NSBs.

In late 1983, the Committee sought and received from the Senate a reference to investigate and report on the activities of NSBs. The Committee tabled an interim report in October 1984, based on information gained from a preliminary survey of all Commonwealth portfolios. The report identified some 300 NSBs and contained data on the method of formation of NSBs, date of formation, membership of NSBs and general information on the costs associated with the operation of NSBs. In its conclusion to the interim report, the Committee recommended that each Commonwealth department include in its annual report a list of the NSBs that fell within its portfolio. The Senate will be interested to note that in the 1984-85 departmental annual reports, 11 departments did not include a list of NSBs, 13 departments did provide a list, and three departments provided a list which included some of their NSBs but did not identify them separately under this title. The remaining department, the Department of Finance, had no NSBs to list.

At the time of tabling the interim report, I informed the Senate that the Committee intended to undertake further investigation into the activities of these bodies. The report I table today is the major part of that further investigation. This report is based on a second, and more extensive, survey of NSBs. The Committee asked that every Minister arrange for the completion of a questionnaire prepared by the Committee by each NSB within his or her portfolio. The Committee found that the response by portfolios to this request ranged from excellent to poor. Some of the departmental officers responsible for ensuring completion of the questionnaire failed to recognise that the questionnaire was a formal request by a parliamentary committee to the Minister for information of NSBs. Other departments failed to check the accuracy of responses and even to keep copies of information they had supplied to the Committee. A number of portfolios still had questionnaires outstanding at the time of the printing of this report, some nine months after the initial request for information.

Despite the difficulties encountered in collecting data, the Committee was able to gain considerable detail and insight on NSB activities for the year 1984-85. A total of 598 NSBs provided completed questionnaires, including some 300 additional NSBs identified by portfolios since the Committee's interim report. The Committee found that all portfolios except Finance had NSBs, with three portfolios each having in excess of 40 NSBs. The Committee was particularly interested in gaining more information on the financial arrangements of NSBs, including the cost of staff, remuneration of members, sources of funding and accountability of NSBs. Unfortunately, the Committee found that it was difficult, if not impossible, for many NSBs to identify their costs. Little detailed information was received by the Committee on the cost of secretariat services, payments to members, including travel allowances and sitting fees, and, surprisingly for some NSBs, how much money they distributed on behalf of the Commonwealth. The Committee also found that only 54 of the 598 NSBs surveyed had published or tabled in the Parliament an annual report in the 1984-85 financial year. Some 144 NSBs had produced a report other than an annual report during that time.

The Committee has made a number of recommendations in this report. Some of the recommendations are an outcome of the difficulties it experienced in collecting information on NSB activities. Others are aimed at increasing NSB accountability to the Parliament and the public. The Committee's principal recommendation is that a central NSB register be created and maintained by a co-ordinating department and that the register be established by 30 June 1987. The Committee strongly believes that such a register should contain, for each NSB, information such as date of establishment, the objectives of the NSB, guidelines for selection of members of the NSB, financial arrangements, and reporting requirements.

The Committee also recommends that in future no NSBs be established without ministerial approval. This will ensure full ministerial knowledge and responsibility even when the establishment of an NSB is not a ministerial initiative. In relation to NSBs already in existence, the Committee recommends that Ministers initiate reviews of their operations with a view to rationalising their work and numbers. The Committee has made a specific recommendation in relation to the accounting standards and procedures of NSBs. The Committee expects this recommendation will be considered by the Minister for Finance as a matter of priority.

I come now to a number of matters which involve not only this inquiry, but also the Committee's work on other Commonwealth bodies. The Committee experienced difficulties in classifying whether particular bodies are NSBs, whether bodies are statutory authorities or parts of departments. After considering the matter at length, the Committee has decided that a number of changes should be made to the way in which the Committee defines and categorises Commonwealth bodies. It is the Committee's intention that these changes will enable the Committee, the Parliament and all other interested groups to distinguish NSBs from statutory authorities.

The changes the Committee intends to adopt are: First, where the enabling legislation of a statutory authority allows the authority to establish a sub-body, then the sub-body has a statutory basis and should be classified as a statutory authority; secondly, government-owned companies, subsidiary companies established by statutory authorities, and associated companies in which statutory authorities have a shareholding of more than 20 per cent, will not be categorised as either NSBs or statutory authorities but will be treated separately along with incorporated associations; and, thirdly, parts of departments, such as the Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics, will not be regarded as NSBs.

As a result of the changes I have outlined, the Committee intends to revise and update its lists of Commonwealth bodies. In future, the Committee intends to publish a list of Commonwealth bodies in the following categories: Statutory authorities; NSBs; and companies and incorporated associations. The Committee hopes to table its revised list of statutory authorities before the end of the year. In order to reflect the three categories of bodies the Committee now wishes to be treated separately and to allow the Committee effectively to pursue its continuing scrutiny of Commonwealth bodies, the Committee proposes that its current terms of reference on statutory authorities and NSBs be amended. In addition, the Committee seeks a new reference on government companies and incorporated associations.

On behalf of the Committee I thank Andrew Snedden, the Secretary to the Committee, Christine McDonald, the research officer to the Committee, and Louise Paton, our steno-secretary, for all their help with the report and their particularly hard work at some crucial points of the report's preparation. In particular, the Committee expresses its thanks to Meg Crooks, who was until recently research officer of the Committee Secretariat. It was she who had the prime carriage of this project from its start and who performed the task of preparing for publication the results of the survey and the first draft of this report. Her ability and dedication in the performance of this onerous and often tedious work are much appreciated. I commend the report to the Senate.
