PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by The President) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to declare the powers, privileges and immunities of each House of the Parliament and of the members and committees of each House, and for related purposes.
Bill presented by The President, and read a first time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The main purpose of this Bill is to avoid the consequences of the very narrow interpretation and reading down of article 9 of the Bill of Rights 1688 in its application to the Australian Parliament in the judgments of Mr Justice Cantor and Mr Justice Hunt of the Supreme Court of New South Wales in each trial in R v Murphy. I have had this Bill prepared and I am submitting it to the Senate in response to requests and suggestions by honourable senators to the effect that a Bill for this purpose should be introduced as soon as possible for consideration by both Houses of the Parliament, and that it would be appropriate, as it is a parliamentary matter, for the President to introduce such a Bill. In so doing I have discussed the matter with the Speaker of the House of Representatives and she concurs with this course of action. I have also included in the Bill, at the request of honourable senators, provisions designed to put into effect the legislative recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege. It was put to me that I should give the Senate the opportunity to consider those recommendations in conjunction with the provisions relating to freedom of speech in Parliament.

It is an unprecedented step for a Presiding Officer of a House of the Parliament to introduce a Bill-indeed, it is unusual for a President to speak to any matter before the Senate at all- but I have decided to take such a step because of the fundamental importance of freedom of speech to the operations of both Houses, and because of the very serious threat to that freedom of speech posed by the judgments to which I have referred. I want to stress once again that the privilege of freedom of speech does not exist for the benefit of members of parliament, but is designed to allow them to speak fearlessly on behalf of the people they represent and to pursue without hindrance matters in the public interest.

In order to assist the Senate in its consideration of the Bill and the matters raised by the judgments in the courts, on 4 June 1986 I presented to the Senate a draft of the Bill, an explanatory memorandum explaining the provisions of the Bill, and a commentary on the judgment of Mr Justice Hunt prepared in the Senate Department. In a statement at that time I invited honourable senators and members to comment on the draft Bill. Some minor refinements have been made to the Bill since the draft was presented. I now present to the Senate an updated explanatory memorandum, and a set of the papers relating to the matter, including the submission which was made to the Court on my behalf and the two judgments. In this second reading speech I will not deal with the provisions which give effect to the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee, as these are fully explained in the explanatory memorandum. I will concentrate on the issue of freedom of speech. Article 9 of the Bill of Rights, which is a statutory provision applying to the Houses of the Australian Parliament by virtue of section 49 of the Constitution, provides:
That the freedom of speech and debates or proceedings in Parliament ought not to be impeached or questioned in any court or place out of Parliament.

It has long been accepted, virtually since this provision was enacted, that this prevents parliamentary proceedings from being called into question in the broadest sense in proceedings before any court or tribunal. This interpretation was supported and applied in a number of judgments in British and Australian courts which are referred to in the documents I have presented to the Senate. These judgments and the long- established interpretation of article 9 which they embodied, however, have been repudiated by the recent judgments given in the Supreme Court of New South Wales. Mr Justice Cantor's judgment, given on 5 June 1985, was to the effect that the test of a breach of article 9 is any adverse effect on parliamentary proceedings, and that the protection provided by article 9 must be balanced against the requirement of court proceedings. It was not clear what this judgment meant in practice until, in the course of the trial, witnesses and the accused were rigorously cross-examined on the evidence which they gave to the Senate committees-including evidence given during in camera committee proceedings-the truth of that evidence was questioned, and submissions were made to the jury as to the credibility of witnesses and the accused based on that questioning.

In his judgment, Mr Justice Hunt ruled that this use of parliamentary proceedings is not in breach of article 9 because the latter is restricted to preventing the prosecution or suit of a person for what that person has said or done in the actual course of the parliamentary proceedings. According to this judgment, it is not a breach of article 9 to use parliamentary proceedings as evidence of an offence or of a civil liability, to establish the motive or intention of a person for the purpose of proving an offence or a civil liability, or to attack the credibility of a person.

This judgment may not necessarily be followed by other courts, and, indeed, a contradictory judgment has already been given. In Australian Broadcasting Commission and Another v Chatterton and Chapman v Chatterton, on 12 August 1986, the Acting Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of South Australia, Mr Justice Zelling, adhered to the traditional interpretation of article 9, notwithstanding that the judgment and reasons of Hunt, J were submitted to him. He held that what was said in Parliament by a defendant in a defamation action could not be used to support the cause of action by adding to or explaining what was said outside Parliament. His Honour stated:

What was said in Parliament cannot be used to extend the meaning of what was said outside Parliament . . . the `untruth' relied on by the Judge [in the trial the subject of appeal] could only be proved by using the appellant Chapman's words in Parliament.
His Honour also rejected a submission that the member of parliament in question had waived his privilege, stating that such a waiver is not possible.

The questions involved in the interpretation of article 9 have also been raised in the trial in the New South Wales Supreme Court in R v Jackson and Others, in which the Crown proposed to use statements by one of the defendants in Parliament as evidence of conspiracy on the part of the defendant. I am advised that the judge in that case, Mr Justice Carruthers, would not allow such use of the defendant's statements in Parliament, but has not yet given his reasons.

Apart from these contradictory court judgments, there are many arguments in favour of the view that the interpretation by Hunt, J of article 9 is not correct. In particular, Hunt, J relies upon an historical analysis of the reasons behind the enactment of article 9 which is not complete and ignores some of the history. I will not go into these arguments here, as they are more fully set out in the documents which I have presented. Instead, I will concentrate on the effects of the judgment.

The narrow reading down of article 9 contained in the judgments of Hunt, J would, if followed, pose a serious threat to the freedom of speech of members of parliament, to whom it applies, as well as to witnesses before parliamentary committees. According to the judgment, while a member may not be sued or prosecuted for something the member has said or done in the actual course of parliamentary proceedings, the member's participation in those parliamentary proceedings can be used against the member to establish the member's motive or intention in relation to words said or acts done outside Parliament and to support an action, civil or criminal, in relation to such words or acts. Thus, in a defamation suit taken against a member for something the member said outside Parliament, the necessary element of malice for success of the suit can be proved by evidence as to something the member said or did in Parliament. To prove a criminal offence against a member in respect of something the member said or did outside Parliament, the member's words or actions in Parliament can be used to establish guilty motive or intention or as evidence of the offence. If a member were called as a witness in a civil or criminal action it would be open to counsel to cross-examine the member on the member's contribution to parliamentary proceedings for the purpose of discrediting the member's evidence.

It is clear, therefore, that the judgment of Hunt, J would allow a member's participation in parliamentary proceedings to be used against the member in court proceedings in a way not thought possible hitherto. Such a situation is clearly a serious inroad on the freedom of speech in Parliament and ought not to be countenanced. The judgment would allow similar use to be made of evidence given by witnesses before parliamentary committees. Senators who have participated in inquiries by the Senate will know that the protection afforded to witnesses by article 9 is often vital in ensuring that witnesses give full and frank evidence. In particular, witnesses have often given evidence which is necessary for the purposes of an inquiry and which could, if given elsewhere, expose them to the risk of civil or criminal action, or be used as evidence of an offence or a civil liability. The judgment of Hunt, J obviously drastically reduces the protection afforded to witnesses by parliamentary inquiries, and would make the securing of full evidence more difficult in the future. Indeed, it may well create a situation where witnesses, with what they would see as justification, are reluctant to accept the invitation to attend and give evidence. As honourable senators who have worked on committees will immediately recognise, this would lead to grave problems in continuing the present committee system, perhaps forcing the use of compulsive measures, which many would see as undesirable, and, in many cases, unproductive. If the Senate were forced to use its powers-which it has not used to a large extent in the past-of compelling witnesses to give evidence under threat of punishment, it obviously would be unfair to leave those witnesses exposed to the use of that evidence against them in future court proceedings. The Bill would prevent such use of parliamentary proceedings and would uphold the long-established interpretation of article 9.

The Bill proceeds from the starting point that article 9 is part of the law of Australia under section 49 of the Constitution, and then indicates that it is to be given the broad and previously-established interpretation. There are two reasons for framing the Bill in this fashion: First, because the Bill must start with a general declaration of the immunity of parliamentary proceedings from question or examination, and the language of article 9 is difficult to improve upon; and, secondly, to make clear the Parliament's belief that article 9 should properly be interpreted, as the Bill provides, and always should have been interpreted that way. Article 9 is part of the law in many jurisdictions around the world, including the Australian States, and it might well create difficulties for the various parliaments in those jurisdictions if the Commonwealth Parliament is seen to be accepting that article 9 has the narrow meaning attributed to it by the recent judgments, and that it is necessary to add to that meaning to establish the broader immunity of parliamentary proceedings from question in the courts. In relation to this point, there is included in the papers I have presented a letter from the Speaker of the New Zealand House of Representatives. The Bill would also prohibit the unauthorised use of evidence taken in camera and not released by a committee or the House concerned. Such unauthorised use of in camera evidence occurred in both trials in R v Murphy.

In commending the Bill to the Senate, I would again draw the attention of honourable senators to the documents which I have presented, and indicate that I look forward to the deliberations of honourable senators on the Bill. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 March, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Trade Union Training Authority Amendment Bill 1986 is essentially a Bill designed to iron out the consequences of the Government bulldozing through Parliament in May 1985, in the dying stages of the autumn session, an omnibus Bill which, contrary to accepted practice, made some very significant amendments to the law. This Bill should not be necessary, because the accepted practice is that governments regularly correct technical amendments to a whole series of enactments in one Bill in an administrative procedure, through what have come to be known as Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bills. I suggest that basically such Bills are inappropriate, but if they only correct minor matters, perhaps they are acceptable. But the risk is, of course, that by doing things in that manner we create a very cumbersome system of law which turns out in addition to be expensive, rather than aiming for what should be the goal-the law being both simple and inexpensive.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, in May 1985, in the dying stages of the parliamentary session, when few senators had time to examine the Bill in detail, we were presented with the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1) 1985 which included very significant changes to the Trade Union Training Authority Act. It passed through the Senate at the time. It was pointed out by Opposition spokesmen that it was not appropriate in an omnibus Bill to make wholesale amendments to a piece of legislation, which it sought to do, especially when it sought to change the structure of a semi-government organisation. The Government cannot say that it was not warned that this was not the way to go about things. It cannot say that it was not warned that if it wanted to change the governing body and its structure, it should do so by a substantive Bill so that we all knew what we were debating and had had time to read and comprehend it. But the Government deliberately pressed on and now, a year later, we are going through the time-wasting and expensive procedure of rectifying the mistake.

The second reading speech is Hawkespeak at its best and is an attempt to hide what occurred. Of course, this cannot be done. The explanatory memorandum sets out quite clearly what is required, and that is an amendment to the Trade Union Training Authority Act to ensure that the staff representative on each State regional council established by the Act is elected from the officers within that State who are relevant to the regional council and not by others who may be in the State but attached to the national level. This was not what was achieved in the amendment rushed through last year.

We recognise that the mistake needs to be rectified and we do not oppose this being done, but we hope that it will be a lesson to the Government to reflect on what we said in 1985 and not to seek to legislate in this manner. The Government must not introduce substantive changes in the law by means of omnibus legislation. It must not proceed in a way that precludes senators having an opportunity to study such a Bill and to consider the changes that are being made by means of that Bill. As I said, the Opposition does not oppose the Bill, but we hope that this sort of procedure will not be repeated in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Trade Union Training Authority Amendment Bill 1986. As the previous speaker, Senator Reid, said, the Government is seeking to make certain amendments because of errors it has made. The Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) made the following point in his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill relates to the participation of officers and employees of the Trade Union Training Authority in the election of staff representatives to the regional councils for trade union training established in each State under the Trade Union Training Authority Act 1975.

This Bill comes before the Senate against the background of a severe economic crisis in Australia, a crisis which is likely to continue and even be aggravated over many months ahead. It also comes before us at a time when the Australian community has shown a growing and heightened criticism of the trade union movement. I rise primarily because of that background.

In Australia, as in many countries, there is a tendency for public opinion to be expressed in violence. I believe, and I have said this in the Senate many times, that the extreme actions of certain sections of the trade union movement have deserved very severe criticism and censure by the Parliament and by the people of Australia. I equally believe that it would be utterly wrong for the public of Australia in its criticisms literally to throw out the baby with the bath water. Essentially, what we need to do in looking at this Bill and at those matters which relate to trade unionism in Australia, is ask ourselves what role should be played by trade unionism in the future. We ought to face up to the need to eliminate the extremes. However, we should fundamentally preserve that role which was designed in the past for trade unionism. That role, of course, was an industrial one; it was not political. It was not a role of interference with management. It was a role which was designed to help union officials ensure that members of a union should have good working conditions in terms of monetary reward, amenities and, of course, the environment in which they work. In fact, over decades trade unionism has brought a considerable benefit to the people of this country.

I have reminded the Senate that trade unionism has emerged from a background of guilds. It is well to remind ourselves of that now because the guilds themselves had a role in preserving the quality of excellence. The guilds were the training grounds for skilled craftsmen. Some of the words in our own language are based on French words. From the French word `aprendre' we derived the word `apprentice'-the taking in of the young. After the apprentice had been trained we then had the journee man, or journeyman, and then onwards to describe the demonstration of skill, the master. That in itself was inherent in the true nature of the trade union. However, the people of Australia have come to realise that some trade unions, and particularly some trade union officials, have well exceeded those powers by using both industrial and political intervention in areas beyond what was deemed to be their true role.

One of the basic reasons I have risen is to say that we should not broadcast criticism or damnation of all trade unions but that we should have an understanding of where the damage has been done and get some idea of how it can be rectified. The fact is that a great majority of the 300-odd trade unions in Australia go about their business in a proper fashion and do not cause trouble. Of course, because of the State and Federal industrial arbitration systems in Australia there have been difficulties in determining jurisdiction and in determining demarcation between particular skills. We have now reached a situation where a series of concepts have grown which Australia can no longer afford. Not only persons such as myself but also leaders and former leaders of the trade union movement such as Mr Charles Fitzgibbon are realising the great dangers in this country due to confrontation. If Australia is to emerge from its present situation, we have to change from a confrontationist society to a co-operative society. That is fundamental. Not only must the trade unions themselves look to their responsibilities; all elements within society must equally do so. Management must look to its responsibilities to see that the work force has decent conditions and that workers share the benefits of their labour in terms of the contribution they make. Governments must play their part in getting off the back of industry, in getting off the back of both management and workers, in creating a particular environment. I think perhaps the best evidence of what ought to change now has come from a variety of statements made by Mr Charles Fitzgibbon.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has this to do with the Bill? You would never have let us get away with this. You would never have let us get away with being so irrelevant to the Bill when you were Leader.

—Mr Deputy President, I am perfectly happy to relate my remarks to the Bill. It is quite clear that this Bill seeks to amend the Trade Union Training Authority Act. The Authority gets to the heart of training trade unionists in the responsibilities of carrying out the duties of unions. That is specifically what I am talking about and I invite you, Mr Deputy President, to take note of that. I can understand Senator Ray's sensitivity in not wanting to hear what I have to say. His Government and his Party have pursued confrontation as their very reason for existence. The Australian Labor Party has always taught that class conflict exists. Indeed, it has fed on that belief. I am grateful for Senator Ray's interjection. The Labor Party has talked consensus but has practised confrontation. Lest anyone should have any doubts about this, I take it that the Labor Party will not object to what was said by Mr Charles Fitzgibbon. In a submission earlier this year to a government body, Mr Fitzgibbon said:

SPEECH.PARA: The current Australian example of a social accord is only an agreement between an organised trade union movement and one political party which holds government at this point of time.

In other words, it is not a consensus at all; it is simply an agreement between the Australian Council of Trade Unions and a Labor Party government-indeed, an agreement no doubt reached by the duress of the ACTU. I quote Mr Charles Fitzgibbon against the background that we have had confrontation over the years and that we need now to move towards co-operation. Indeed, every major country which is out-competing us at the moment in terms of exports and which is flooding this country with its imports has a co-operative government as distinct from the confrontation that has been built up here. The present Hawke Government has always had a background of confrontation. For example, the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his role as President of the ACTU was always confrontationist. Let me just quote what was said by Mr Hawke in August 1974 at a time when there was rising inflation and people were being shed from manufacturing industry. This is what Mr Hawke, as President of the ACTU, said:

We know inflation is at 16 per cent and we believe it's quite likely to reach 20 per cent in the next two quarters. But we will not indulge in a trade-off in wages for some conjectural reduction in inflation.

As everyone knows, as a result of Mr Hawke's confrontationist leadership, the rate of inflation at that time ran up beyond 17 1/2 per cent on the way to 20 per cent and the Whitlam Government was thrown out. It has been that kind of confrontation, combined with his leadership in 1981, that has caused the disaster that the trade union movement faces today. The trade union movement has responsibilities not only to its members but also to the 600,000 unemployed in Australia. Fundamentally, the job of government and unions is to ensure that people have the opportunity to work in the job of their choice and to receive fair remuneration. In looking at the role of co-operation of trade unionism in Australia Mr Fitzgibbon, in his paper to the Economic Planning Advisory Council, said:

A grab by trade unions now for a bigger slice of the economic cake could destroy opportunities for growth because this would result in self-defeating inflation and lost competitiveness in our traded goods and service industries.

He said that 20 or 30 times in his paper, and then he went on to say something of great importance. He said that it is no longer possible for us to argue that in Australia we are competing against countries that have lower wages. He continued:

It should be understood that an Australian worker does not get greater pay than his German/Japanese or American counterpart, in most cases he gets less and total labour costs per employee are generally less, but it is in the bottom line figure at the end of the day as to the productive cost that shows the difference in result per dollar.
He said:
In other words it is necessary to keep educating portions of the community to an understanding of the advantages of the material gains inherent in a more cooperative productive society.

If there is to be a basis for the future in the training of trade unions, in terms of the understanding of the community and what the role of unionism is to be inside the community, in a co-operative way, it must be based on the premises outlined by Mr Fitzgibbon. Surely, it must be based on the fact that, in Australia, there is no vital difference between the interests of management and worker-their interests are the same.

Every other country, especially Japan, knows that both the worker and the management have a vested interest in the prosperity of the enterprise itself. They understand that to have efficiency, delays and strikes is to punish the enterprise. But they understand something that Australia must come to understand, and that is this: No one section of the community-government, management, worker or trade union-can benefit for any length of time by scoring off the other. No one section of the community can hold the rest of the community to ransom without in the long run punishing itself and the rest of the community. Sadly, that is what we have found. Sadly, in the early 1970s with the disastrous loss of working days in the Whitlam years, there was the shedding of 110,000 people manufacturing, a real fall in our ability to create jobs and the loss of our competitiveness with the rest of the world. As Mr Fitzgibbon has said, we cannot chase wages upwards unless the community can pay. He said:

It is accepted by realists that unless movements in labour costs are in line with economic capacity and growth in productivity the result will be to the detriment of organised labour and Australians generally.

What he is saying is that the minimum wage must be fixed on the capacity of industry, the community, to pay, and if we fix it above that, as has been done over the years, sadly, all we do is create an illusion for the Australian worker. All we do is cost him out of his living standards and jobs for his children. We must ensure that our system is based on the capacity of industry to pay and that, inside that capacity, proper margins for skill and incentives are given to individual employees.

For far too long, we have failed to give proper incentives to Australian workers. For far too long-management is as much to blame for this as anybody-the most highly skilled craftsmen have been paid the same as the most poorly skilled craftsmen. That has created an institutionalised mediocrity in Australia. That is a tragedy for Australia because the Australian worker is a good worker. The Australian worker wants to be skilled and he wants to show his abilities and productivity. We have created a position which makes us uncompetitive with the world outside. The Hawke Government continues to say that the reason for our decline is based on the fact that export prices have fallen in terms of our minerals and agricultural industries. It fails to say the fundamentally important thing that, on the other side of the ledger, Australia is swamped with imports flooding into this country at a cost with which our industries cannot compete. The effect of that is very simple. Because our industries are not competitive, our people do not have jobs.

What a strange thing it is that the Hawke Government does not talk about the real side of the balance sheet-that is, jobs and people's living standards. Unless we can get our competitiveness and productivity up, and our costs down, those imports will flood in or, alternatively, what will happen in prolonged point will be what is happening now. The Government will continue to lower the capacity of purchasing power to stop people buying the flood of imports. That is a disastrous policy in the long term. Fancy a policy being sustained by any responsible government to cut down on the volume of money to stop people being able to buy. The job of the Government, in the end, is to lift up the capacity to pay.

At this stage, it is necessary to put confrontation aside, whichever side of the work force or the factory floor it occurs. We must leave the word `confrontation' out of our language. We must show the people of Australia that the way back can be taken in one of two ways: The constructive way, which will create jobs and preserve living standards, or the destructive way-that is the course we are on now-which lowers living standards and which will, on the Government's own statement, create more unemployment. As the Budget said, there will be more unemployment in the months ahead.

The constructive way is to get increased productivity-that is, to get to the heart of the factory floor, to get to the relationship of good managerial procedures, good technological skills and good co-operation. There should be an understanding that the worker deserves incentive rewards, be they bonuses, profit sharing, shares in the company, or whatever. Fundamentally, that is the key to Australia's future. If we do not get our productivity up, if we go downhill in the way we are doing now, we will have fewer jobs and lower living standards. I repeat Mr Fitzgibbon's words:
In other words it is necessary to keep educating portions of the community to an understanding of the advantages of the material gains inherent in a more co-operative productive society.
I could not agree more. He continued:

It doesn't take too much imagination in respect of any undertaking to work out that if you could improve productivity by any percentage then that almost certainly equates a reduction in the cost of the article by a similar amount and in most industries or enterprises it would not be difficult to produce significant results.

The Trade Union Training Authority is an institution designed to train trade unionists, to train people in a proper industrial understanding of their responsibilities. We should look to where we are in terms of the community and its understanding of unions; we should look to the role of the unionist; we should set aside any kind of desire, however emotional and wrongly directed, simply to do a broadcast attack on unionists as a whole; and we should ask: What do we want? We want a co-operative system of management, worker and government. We want an understanding that the interests of worker and management are identical, that the role of government is to get off the back of both in terms of lower taxes and charges and fewer unnecessary regulations and to get right to the heart of the situation.

What we should be saying to the people of Australia is fundamental: The main countries that are competing with and defeating us throughout the world-countries such as Japan, Singapore and Germany-lack fundamentally the physical resources that we have in Australia but they have the fire in their belly and the understanding of co-operation to co-operate and get on with the job. We in Australia basically have all the fundamental physical resources and, with our huge deposits of coal, the ability to generate virtually unlimited electrical energy. All we need is the application and the team-work to combine the two to produce a result which must out-compete the rest of the world.

I have said in the Senate many times that it is an outrage to our common sense that we cart iron ore to Japan-50 per cent of it dirt-in one ship and coal to Japan in another, have the material smelted and rolled into flat steel and buy the product back at a cheaper price than what we could produce it for here. Yet some 20 or 25 years ago we could boast that we produced the cheapest flat steel in the world. It is all tied up with the fundamental approach not only to how we train trade unionists but also to how the community sees trade unions, how trade unionism sees itself in relation to management and how governments see themselves in relation to the various elements-be they trade unions, management or the rest of the community.

If we are to have a consensus in this community it must not be simply a behind-the-door arrangement between the ACTU and the government of the day. That is simply not good enough. Indeed, it is not good enough to bring in some elements of management and seek to do something there. The community consists of a wide range of people. It consists of many self-employed people who have no such voice, many people on fixed incomes who suffer enormously if things go wrong and people on pensions.

To pull this argument together, I say this: If we in Australia are to get our community back on the road, to get jobs for our young, to get our living standard secure, to make Australia a go-ahead nation, we have to be competitive with the rest of the world. Fundamentally, the only sensible way to do that is to get increased productivity by co-operation. We cannot do that if there is still inherent in this country some nineteenth century beliefs of class warfare and class conflict. We cannot do that if the extremes in any part of industry are such that all we do is abuse each other. What we have to do is understand that we are as one, that no one can score off the other and that no one can gain in the long run if the other is losing. We cannot envisage a situation in which management can in some way benefit and prosper in the long term by grinding down the work force. That is an eighteenth or nineteenth century illusion anyhow. Some 80 per cent or more of the people who buy the goods and services that management produces are the ordinary workers on the factory floor or in offices. Unless they are prosperous, unless they have real purchasing power, management cannot be prosperous, except in the short term, and it knows that. Equally the work force must come to understand that unless its firm is prosperous the work force cannot prosper.

In Japan most social service benefits come from industry, so there is a direct understanding between management and worker. I am told that when a Japanese goes on strike he puts on a black armband and works twice as hard. In Australia what we have to do to turn the ship around is to turn around attitudes. We have to put aside the shibboleths and the confrontational nature of the past. It is no good simply saying to one section: `You must take cuts'. We have to say to everybody: `The way ahead is co-operation. You all have to share in it. None can succeed at the expense of the other. Let us get our act together in full co-operation'.

—Whatever has been said in the past, this Government has led the country into a crisis. That crisis now has to be dealt with. The simple point that I make is that it is not in the interests of Australia to contemplate new taxes on this or any other industry. Rather, we should be looking to a reduction of the tax burden which will encourage further investment and activity in this country.
—Seek refuge in magic; that is your formula.

—As I said, I welcome the interjections from Senator Walsh because whilst at times he makes extremely valuable contributions to the economic debate at other times he allows his unbridled prejudices to run away with him. This is another area in which we can expect the exercise of his prejudice to be allowed full rein. It will be interesting to see whether the views of the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, triumph in the halls of the Australian Labor Party or whether the views of members of the Party, particularly back bench members who are alive to the electoral risks involved in a new gold tax, triumph.

SPEECH.PARA: I make it quite clear that it is the view of the Opposition that the Government is moving in the correct direction in removing the 2 per cent revenue duty. It is not moving in the correct direction when it foreshadows a new tax on the gold mining industry, an industry which at the moment is serving Australia particularly well. Last year, the Australian gold mining industry earned over $600m in export income. Over 90 per cent of gold production is exported. It is our fourth largest mineral export. In 1984-85 gold production totalled 49 tonnes, the highest level since 1940, and production has been growing at a phenomenal rate-by around 50 per cent per annum. The industry employs around 5,000 people directly and another 8,500 are estimated to be employed indirectly in related activities.

Investment and exploration expenditure in the industry is high. There was expenditure of about $483m in 1984-85. That is expected to increase markedly in the current year and beyond. The Australian Goldmining Industry Council estimates that annual investment and exploration expenditure in the industry could grow to $1 billion per year. This is encouraging in a Budget year in which the Government is predicting, as I said before, a one per cent reduction in private investment. Here is an industry which is substantially expanding its investment and in which production has been growing at a rate of about 50 per cent per annum.

The Opposition is concerned to try to maintain the expansion of activity in this industry which industry sources confidently expect to continue. I want to use the occasion of debate on this Bill, which takes a step in the right direction-it encourages the gold mining industry and the possibility of further international trade in gold involving storage in Australia and so on to Australia's economic benefit-to urge the Government to put aside the possibility of a new tax on gold that it has been canvassing over the last year or more. I have given figures which indicate to what extent the gold mining industry is contributing to the economic health of this country at a time when there are far too few positive indications. The Australia-wide contribution is quite clear. Obviously a very great regional contribution is being made in a number of States, not least in my State of Western Australia. One has only to visit Kalgoorlie to see the enormous change which has been wrought in that community by the revival of the gold mining industry.

What has happened in the recent past is confidently predicted to continue. We have great hopes of continued high levels of domestic activity. Concerning export income, we have great hopes and very reasonable expectations that there will be further expansion, to Australia's great advantage. The Australian Goldmining Industry Council said that the projected production suggests the export value of gold in 1986, if it is at an average value of $A400 an ounce, will be worth around $780m, rising to over $800m in 1987.

TALK.START.PARA: —What increase does that represent on last year?

—It was around $600m last year. So this area has had a very worthwhile increase. The attitude which might have prevailed in easier times was that rationally one should seek simply to apply the same level of taxation at the lowest possible level but spread as evenly as possible over all industries. Given the qualities of gold, which include its salability under any circumstances, its potential to remain a very valuable export and its potential to remain a growth area in an economy which is struggling to find growth areas, this is simply not the time to impose new cost burdens and, particularly, it is not the time to impose new taxes on gold. There is a great deal of uncertainty at the moment in the community about a possible gold tax. The Government has already moved to affect the gold mining industry and other industries by the imposition of a capital gains tax and a fringe benefits tax. They impose additional costs on this industry. Gold exploration and production, by its very nature, is undertaken because of the possibility of very high rewards. But the corollary is that many investments are likely to attract very little reward. In those circumstances a capital gains tax is an important disincentive to new investment.

SPEECH.PARA: The fringe benefits tax is particularly relevant because gold is often mined in the remoter parts of Australia. Industries which operate in remote parts of Australia tend to have to rely on fringe benefits, not so much as a method of tax reduction and not as some tax rort, which is what the Government talks about, but as a means of obtaining labour under conditions which are roughly equal to the more temperate and easier to live in parts of Australia. I suggest to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce that there is a very great difference between providing housing assistance, power assistance and some transport assistance to people who are working in regions such as the Pilbara, the eastern goldfields of Western Australia or the remote areas of the Northern Territory, and providing such assistance to people who are living in Vaucluse or Peppermint Grove. There really are substantial reasons for undertaking the differential treatment and the provision of support for staff through what are now defined as taxable fringe benefits. I suggest to the Government that the fringe benefits tax therefore represents a particularly heavy burden on industries such as the gold mining industry. Up to this point I have been very surprised at the relatively modest assessments of cost that have been put out by the mining industry generally about the impact of the fringe benefits tax. I note that over recent days the Australian Mining Industry Council has indicated that it expects mining companies to have to pay between $70m and $80m per annum in fringe benefits tax. The point I make is that very few mining companies are making a substantial return on the capital which is utilised by those companies and many of them are operating in a fiercely competitive environment. The situation is one where new tax burdens should be undertaken with very great care, if at all.

I must say also that it is rather horrifying to realise, from Question Time today and from earlier questioning, that there has been very little attempt by the Government to relate this new tax impost to the particular position of different industry segments and to the overall costs which will be incurred by industry in an administrative sense as well as a taxation sense. I believe there has been a tremendous sloppiness in this part of the Government's approach to industry, a lack of concern about the way these tax changes will impact on individual enterprises and the impact they are likely to have on the investment decisions and the general business decisions of those individual enterprises. It was my experience in government that tax proposals were sometimes produced by the bureaucracy without much regard for the microeconomic effects. There seemed to me to be little tradition of undertaking an analysis of the actual impact of the tax on any particular industry or indeed on a company where it might have a major share of a particular industry output. It was my experience on one occasion to see a proposed levy on a mineral being brought forward for consideration by Cabinet for which, on questioning, there was simply no evidence available as to how that would impact on the profitability of the companies involved in that industry.

I refer to that piece of history because I think it is clear from the history of the present Government that a number of significant tax decisions which impact quite severely on the industries which the Minister at the table, Senator Button, is trying to encourage, have been imposed by the Government without any detailed consideration of how they will affect industries either at the general level or at the enterprise level. I suggest that there is a drastic need for the procedures of Treasury and the Department of Finance to be improved so that governments are given a better analysis of what the impact of tax changes is likely to be than has been given in the past. I do not want to go back at great length over the history of these matters, but I would like to refer again to Question Time today. It seems clear from the answers Senator Button gave that in the present case the Government had no real figures before it on the impact of the fringe benefits tax, on important industry sectors or on the administrative costs that would be borne by private industry. I suggest that that sort of contemptuous approach is the product not of a government that does not care about these matters but of a bureaucracy that is simply not in any way trained to be concerned about the essential bottom line considerations of business, which are so irrelevant to the operation of bureaucracies that are themselves funded by the taxpayer.

The Australian Goldmining Industry Council, which of course is an industry group that represents the interests of gold producers, predicts that the taxing of the gold industry at the full corporate rate will dramatically undermine investment exploration, employment and output in the industry itself as well as in the economy overall. I venture to suggest to the Minister that he should ask his Department to examine the importance of the gold mining industry to the heavy engineering sector, which he is currently trying to put on a better basis by offering incentives and changes. He would find that that is a quite important source of work. It would not, of course, rival the North West Shelf, with its massive single investment which is affecting industry in Western Australia and other States. As part of the Government's consideration of the gold mining tax issue, I ask the Minister to ask his Department to pursue the hard evidence that I think the Government should have before it on the impact of tax changes and reduced activity in the gold mining sector on the heavy engineering industry, which at the moment he is offering $60m of taxpayers' money to try to get into better shape. The fundamental problem for the heavy engineering industry, which I am sure the Minister would concede, is lack of demand. I think we should be very cautious in making changes which will further reduce the demand for those heavy engineering services in the present state of the Australian economy.

Returning to the predictions of the Goldmin- ing Industry Council, it warned of a reduction in national income of half a billion dollars, a reduction in direct and indirect taxes of $100m, and 13,000 jobs lost. Imposition of the tax would seriously reduce gold exports and foreign exchange earnings when we are experiencing a balance of payments crisis. These predictions of job losses and reduced activity are the common staff of debate when we are looking at industry issues, whether they are tariff issues or issues of tax change. I again appeal to the Minister not to deal with this matter on the basis of generalisations but actually to seek, either from the co-ordinating departments of Finance and/or Treasury or from his own Department, the hardest possible evidence of the impact which can be expected. The reality is that when we look at our hard pressed mining industry overall we see that it has in fact performed magnificently in the face of very difficult international competition. If we look at the state of the world mining industry in the late 1960s and early 1970s and at the companies which were the leading international companies in base metals, for example, at that time, and if we turn our attention to the state of the world mining industry in the mid-1980s, we will see an extraordinary and creditable record of survival in the Australian industry which I believe the American majors of the late 1960s and early 1970s would envy. In part that survival is based on some very good natural resources in Australia, but in part it is based on a very fine effort by the mining industry at the management and labour force levels. I note that Senator Sheil, who I think comes from a mining family, is in the chamber. I think our mining industry is in world class. It is an area of Australian industry of which we are entitled to be very proud. I suggest to the Government that it is operating in an international environment in which the virtual collapse of major international companies should warn the Government that it should not be putting on new imposts under almost any circumstances.

My concern in debating a Bill which the Opposition supports, because it is in fact removing a burden from the gold industry and we believe it is a step in the right direction, is that in making this relatively minor step forward the Government might at the same time be moving in ways which are quite destructive of the long term interests of this country. This is an issue which needs to be looked at without the prejudice that I think is often attached to these matters. I do not believe that the Government can any longer believe that the mining industry is a milch cow for the rest of the economy. In the interests of trying to be as bipartisan as possible in this debate, I point to some of the things we felt able to do in government in terms of putting levies on the coal mining industry, which were then partially removed and which I think have been partly lifted by this Government, but the remnants of which still remain. I think those days are over and in all our approaches to industry, whether it is the gold mining industry, the mining industry generally or other sectors, our every effort should be turned towards removing costs and burdens, and the important part of the costs and burdens of industry are the taxes which are imposed by government. I welcome the opportunity to say something about an industry which is of vital importance to my State, of vital importance to the Northern Territory, and of importance, if less vital importance, to a number of other regions in Australia. I commend the Government for taking a step in favour of freeing up the trade involved, a step, I believe which is likely to be of value to this country.

I close by referring to an article I wrote about a tax on gold mining in February 1984, some of which has been quoted as a suggestion that I am arguing in favour of the taxation of gold. I refer to the end of that article and say that if we look at the way the gold mining industry has prospered over recent years perhaps logic should lead us not to say that we should tax that industry more; perhaps logic should lead us to say that we might see similar benefits in the rest of the Australian mining industry if we reduce tax burdens on it. I do not think that there is any doubt that our great coal mining industry which is a producer of so much wealth for this country would be able to do much more if it were subjected to less onerous burdens by both State and Federal governments. I do not think that there is any doubt that the whole mining sector would benefit if we were able to reduce many of the costs which afflict it generally and many of the complexities of government administration which make the opening of a new mine in Australia so difficult and so complex. I commend the legislation and I simply ask the Government to make this legislation, which removes a burden from the gold industry, a pattern for the future rather than the exception to the general approach of the Government.
