SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1986, the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1986 and the Sales Tax Acts Amendment Bill 1986 seek to impose a range of new taxes on some goods and services which are presently subject to sales tax and some which are not. This legislation stems from two failures of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) over the last year or so. The first failure was when he failed at the National Taxation Summit in July last year to convince the union lobby, the leader of his Party-the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-and the welfare lobby that there was an honourable case for moving the balance of taxation away from income tax in favour of indirect taxes such as a broad-based consumption tax. He failed dismally. He failed in the back rooms of the Australian Labor Party when the unions put the pressure on the Prime Minister and forced him to withdraw his support for the Treasurer's proposed introduction of a broad-based consumption tax. The benefits that would have flowed from the introduction of such a tax were spelt out by the Government in its White Paper on taxation and had the in-principle support of the Opposition at that time, notwithstanding that we believed that the particular measure the Government had in mind seemed to go too far at the time and in too much of a hurry.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer's second failure stems from the fact that when the Government scrambled to put its Budget together at the end of July it had no alternative but to raise taxes to reduce the Budget deficit to $3 1/2 billion. That necessity was imposed upon it by the dramatic fall in the value of the dollar which resulted directly from the Government's economic policies. Instead of taking the knife to government expenditure, the Government decided to raise an extra $1 1/2 billion by way of taxation to get the deficit down. There was a failure by the Government to address the real issue required to be addressed by it, that is, the cutting of its own expenditure to ensure that the deficit was credible so that the financial markets would see the measure as being a step in the right direction. Again the Treasurer failed. The Government, in its attempt to reduce the Budget deficit by $2.2 billion, raised $1.5 billion extra from the people of Australia by way of heavy taxation. It failed to meet the very real test of being able to take the knife to government expenditure.

This legislation is of particular concern to South Australia and to my constituents. Again the Government has blundered, seeking to impose taxes on two critical agricultural and horticultural products of South Australia-wine and citrus fruit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to do something about it, Senator?

—I will come to that a little later. Mr Acting Deputy President, you know, as a South Australian, that those two industries come together in a rather unique part of the State along the Murray River, comprising the great irrigation settlements that were laid out in the earlier part of the century. The main products of this area are grapes for wine and dried fruit production and fruit such as oranges and lemons for the fresh and processed fruit industry. We have seen the Government blunder into imposing an increased tax on the wine industry, raising the tax from the rate of 10 per cent imposed in 1984 to 20 per cent. That flies in the face of a recommendation by the McKay report into the grape growing industry last year which was that we must wait to see what happened to the wine and grape growing industries as a result of the imposition of the first round of taxes imposed in 1984 before we imposed any further taxes. That is the first thing that has been ignored by the Government in its scramble for revenue to reduce the Budget deficit-the independent advice of experts in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, we have been treated in this place for a long period to tirades from the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) about how well the wine and grape industries have been doing in the last few years since the imposition of the 10 per cent tax on wine. The Minister sought, by one distortion or another, to make it seem as though somehow prosperity had been brought to the industry through high taxation of its products. Nothing could be further from the truth. We have seen throughout Australia a decline in the direct employment of those in the wine industry under the first round of tax increases from 6,000 to 5,000. We have also seen the crush of grapes reduced from some 600,000 tonnes last year to some 495,000 tonnes this year. Yet this Government tries to tell us that somehow the industry is prosperous and going ahead as a result of the taxes the Government has imposed. Nothing could be further from the truth. It is utterly ludicrous for this Government to keep pressing that point. It is a point which certainly cannot be accepted by the industry or by South Australians, as you, Mr Acting Deputy President, know only too well.

The industry's situation is even worse when one measures sales in dollar terms. Whereas in the 1984-85 financial year there was a sales increase in dollar terms of some 5 per cent, the increase in sales in the year just ended, 1985-86, even though there had been an increase in the price of wine, was only 1.5 per cent. So the industry is in decline. Let me take the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who is at the table, Senator Walsh, the Treasurer and the Prime Minister for a drive through the Clare Valley to let them see what is happening to grape growers in that area. The Minister would be ashamed to think that it is the actions of the Hawke Labor Government which have produced such utter devastation in the area. It is a shocking sight to see this season's grapes still hanging on the vines right throughout that area, to see that virtually every block has a `for sale' sign on it and that no grapes have been taken from the Clare Valley into the co-operative wineries this year, which means that there will be no income for farmers this year. It is a devastating sight. The area looks as though it has been hit by a bomb. The Riverland area is rapidly developing the same kind of appearance, brought about by this Government's unfeeling policies in its scramble to meet an illusory Budget deficit. It strikes me as rather strange that this Government is prepared to put $8m into a vine pull scheme which is designed to get farmers out of grape production at a time when it is imposing a further tax on the industry which will yield some $60m. That is only the start. Other payments will be required by way of social security for the farmers who are now unable to look after themselves as a result of what is happening.

Quite clearly, this industry is in crisis and it deserves the attention of this Government. It does not deserve the imposition of further taxes, such as those that have been imposed by this Government in the Budget. It is interesting to note that, in regard to sales at the wholesale level for the whole wine industry, totalling about $600m, the net profit is only $30m. That represents a return on sales of about 5 per cent. The point that must be made, though, is that government-I include State governments-in imposing taxes on the wine industry takes $240m from the wine industry. That figure includes this latest sales tax impost. It is eight times the after tax net profit of the wine industry. Governments take $240m from wholesale sales worth $600m. This has a devastating effect. It represents a ratio of 8:1 in terms of the profitability of this industry. While other industries, such as the brewing industry, complain about the level of taxes imposed on them, they do not bear anything like the ratio of tax to net income that the wine industry bears. This has a devastating impact on the industry and, quite clearly, will have regional impacts that this Government will be forced to cope with by way of social security payments and other adjustment means.

It is interesting to note that the huge devaluation of the Australian dollar might have been expected to lead to an improvement in export sales of wine. We now find, of course, that that is becoming extraordinarily difficult because the Government has chopped out the export market development grants scheme. It has also, through the devaluation, made it more and more costly for the industry to undertake promotional development of wine products overseas. Of course, because of the imposition of the fringe benefits tax, the industry cannot promote as much of the product overseas without paying tax. The disallowance of entertainment expenses for tax purposes means that it is more difficult for the industry to promote wine in overseas markets. The Government could have offered the wine industry opportunities to help itself out of its troubles. But it is now imposing taxes, such as the fringe benefits tax, and there is the disallowance of entertainment expenses, which together with these sales taxes that are now to be imposed have caused enormous imposts on the industry. The industry's objective of extricating itself from its difficulties has been defeated. The Government is prepared, apparently, to put $8.5m into restructuring the industry through the vine pull scheme. But why would it not-and should it not-consider how it could better use that $8.5m to develop export markets to encourage the wine industry to help itself out of its troubles.

The effect of this taxation is devastating. It will have huge regional effects, particularly when one combines the effect on the wine industry with that which will now occur in the citrus industry. Because of the fall in the price of imported orange juice on world markets, we will no doubt see more and more of that product being used in Australian production. Even though the differential in the rate of tax that is applicable favours the local product, because of the cheapness of the overseas product people will tend to buy that product. Clearly, that will have an effect on regional areas such as the Riverland. This Government, in its typical, unfeeling way, has nothing to say about the regional impact of the taxes. The wine industry and the citrus industry come together in one regional area in South Australia, and, of course, in other parts of Australia as well, such as in Mildura and the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area.

These measures will have a devastating impact in those areas. This will, of course, undermine the other industrial infrastructure which has already been established. I refer, of course, to tourism. Tourism is a vital element in the survival and development of the Riverland in South Australia. That potential will be undermined if the wine and citrus industries are forced to decline. These measures are on top of increases in State charges, such as irrigation and electricity charges, which will cause more difficulties for industry. A very severe change is about to occur in the whole Riverland area as a result of the introduction of these taxes.

The devaluation of the Australian dollar is also having a very significant impact on the cost structure of the wine industry. The value of the dollar, in United States dollar terms, has fallen by 40 per cent in the last year. A very significant part of the cost of the manufacturing of wine is tied up with imported products. I refer, for instance, to the French oak which is used to make wine barrels, which is imported and, consequently, the price of which has risen enormously in recent times; in fact, it has doubled. There has been an increase in the price of corks. The price has gone up by 60 per cent in the last year. The cost of chemicals such as tartaric acid has risen by about 100 per cent in recent times. All these imposts are on top of the ill-considered tax measures which this Government has introduced. The effect in the Riverland, of course, will be enormous.

The one thing that is needed in the whole wine industry-from a regional standpoint, it affects the citrus industry as well-is a stable policy of development. What we need is a considered policy development by this Government on all the issues that I have just mentioned. There is a need for the Minister's Department-the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce-to get together with the Department of the Treasury, the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Primary Industry to work out a stable system so that people in the wine and grape industries and the citrus industry can plan their futures. I think those considerations are absolutely important. To that end, the Liberal and National parties have set up a wine industry study group to look at the regional impact of policy changes in the Riverland and in other parts of Australia, together with the impact on the wine industry of changes in taxation. What this industry needs, above all, is stability, and that is what the Liberal and National parties will give it. That is what the present Government has taken away from it.

This Government introduced a wine tax of 10 per cent in 1984. Of course, the present Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) had already promised that there would be no wine tax under the Hawke Labor Government. There has been also an attempt to tax fortified spirit in the brandy industry. That, of course, had to be modified after considerable pressure had been applied by senators in this place. We now see this increase in the sales tax from 10 to 20 per cent. That is totally beyond the pale in terms of where the industry is heading and in terms of the future development of the whole Riverland region.

One or two other measures in this legislation are of concern to the Opposition. A tax will be applied for the first time to computer software, which will rake in $100m in a full year. That comes about through a change in the way in which software will be taxed in the future, and the Government has chosen to go down that path. Quite clearly, it is something which is going to have an impact upon business costs as more and more businesses in Australia adopt advanced techniques and technology in their information collection systems and so on. Obviously it will have a very significant impact.

Firms that are in the area of employing computers for their manufacturing processes will find enormous increases in the cost of software as a result of this tax and there will be very significant impacts upon their cost structures as a result. It is rather ironic that at a time when we are seeking to develop more and more techniques for increasing production and productivity in this country the Government is failing to recognise that by imposing taxes in this fashion it is working against that objective which I thought was its main objective at this time.

The other taxes that are imposed on milk products are causing considerable concern in the community and have raised very significant questions. Those taxes are affecting dairying industry areas in Australia generally as well as in that part of my State which is concerned with the production of that material. Clearly one has to doubt that the Government thought through the effects of these changes in the tax structure on various products of this kind. Consequently one has to doubt that it really understands what effects, both in employment terms and in production terms, these taxes will have. Certainly the story in South Australia is very clear in that respect. There are going to be some devastating effects in the Riverland area as a result of the introduction of these measures.

I would like to return quickly to the wine industry. It is important to recognise that not only is the wine industry going to be affected by the introduction of this further tax on its products but also that the other matters I mentioned earlier are very significant to the future of the industry. Those matters are the introduction by this Government of the fringe benefits tax and eventually, of course, the capital gains tax. All those farmers who are in the situation where eventually they will have to sell their properties and perhaps reinvest the funds they receive from such sales as they are forced out of the industry will find that the moneys from the sale of those properties will be put into investments that will eventually be the subject of capital gains tax. In this way the Government is contributing to forcing people into a situation where the capital gains tax will apply to their life-long investment in their properties. This assumes, of course, that people are able to sell those many properties that are now on the market and for which clearly there are not a lot of buyers. That is something which will be recognised in the future and which will have a devastating impact for those people and their families.

The fringe benefits tax has caused farmers in this area to have very major concerns about its impact on their cost structures. There are employees who, because of the remoteness of their location and the special circumstances of the industry, are provided with housing. Because of their jobs they are required to and are entitled to use motor cars and so on and consequently their employers will find themselves subject to the fringe benefits tax. There is also the very devastating impact of the entertainment tax, which has had the effect of lowering demand for wine generally in the community and through the hotel and restaurant trades. Clearly that is occurring at a time when all costs are rising in the way in which we have outlined and again it will contribute to the decline of the industry. Surely it is time for the Government to wake up to its mistake in this area.

I think it is also important that the Australian Democrats recognise that, while the industry is in a state of decline, as it is, and has enormous difficulties, the problems do not all stem from the wine tax increase. That is not the only evil. The bigger evil has been the change in the market-place brought about by the entertainment tax, the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax, which is yet to affect it. That has hurt incentive in this nation and I think that consequently the people of the Riverland in South Australia and in others areas would like to know why it is that they have had those taxes foisted on them by the Australian Democrats. Indeed, had the Democrats voted with us a year ago to oppose those devastating taxes we would not have this incredibly stupid piece of fringe benefits tax legislation before us now, which is creating havoc not only in the wine industry but in other industries as well. It is those factors, which have already been acknowledged by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, that will have such a great impact on those people who are struggling to make a living in the wine industry in South Australia.

Finally, the point has to be again acknowledged that the Government has introduced this legislation because of two very significant failures on the part of the Treasurer, Mr Keating. The situation was, as we acknowledged, that, firstly, he failed to get into place a broad-based consumption tax at his ill-starred Taxation Summit in 1985 and, secondly, that he has failed to get a knife into the heart of government expenditure and has been forced to raise more and more taxes in order to meet the Budget deficit forecast announced in the Budget. In fact, his failure in that regard has led to further taxes of $1.5 billion on the Australian people in order to meet that obligation. That has led to the very significant point that this Government has the highest proportion of gross domestic product going to taxes of any government since Federation-some 25.5 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —How does it stand up internationally?

—The Government has broken its very solemn commitment given to the people in the 1984 election campaign that it would not increase, in overall percentage terms of GDP, the amount of money going to taxes. Of course, in the 1986 Budget the Government has exceeded that and it has sought to make some kind of virtue out of the fact, as Senator Button has now just demonstrated by his interjection that he seems to support, that it is a good idea to break promises in circumstances that suit the Government. That is fine. We are getting used to these breaches of promise that continually occur. We saw it happen with the lump sum superannuation tax following the 1983 election. We saw it with the assets test on pensions after the 1983 election when we were told there would be no such assets test. We now have it. This Government cannot be trusted with its promises and consequently we cannot be sure where it will strike next. One thing that is clear is that it will strike where it is most politically advantageous to do so, which is why the people of the Riverland of South Australia, who this Government knows do not vote for its Party, have been hit to leg by this tax on the production of wine. I am sure that the Government will reap the effects of this in other ways and certainly the exchequer will suffer as a result of the introduction of this crazy tax on wine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened very carefully to Senator Messner for half an hour. He waxed eloquent on the problems of the Murray Valley. He waxed eloquent on the fact that this Government is the highest taxing government since Federation; but I still do not know what the Opposition is going to do about it. After hearing this rhetoric about how bad these taxes are, is the Opposition going to go to water and, weak kneed, support the Government in passing the very thing that Senator Messner spent so much time talking about?

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats are concerned with three parts of this sales tax legislation. We will very shortly be circulating amendments which we will move at the Committee stage to attack the very abuses about which Senator Messner spoke so eloquently. The Democrats also are concerned about the new wine tax-the increase of the tax on wine and cider from 10 to 20 per cent. There is to be a sudden 10 per cent sales tax increase on a young and vibrant industry. We are also very concerned about the imposition of a 10 per cent tax on milk, fruit juices and non-alcoholic wines. The Democrats have defined these products as basic necessities of life. In 1982 we opposed taxing the basic necessities of life. Although at that time all Democrat senators had a six-year term in front of them, we were prepared to go to the barricades and oppose the taxing of the necessities of life. Certainly we are going to do so again this time. We will be moving amendments that will have the effect of opposing the 10 per cent impost on the necessities of life. The third aspect of this sales tax legislation that we are very concerned about is the 20 per cent tax on the computer software industry which, again, is another developing and thriving industry in this country. As soon as this industry begins to get somewhere we suddenly find that a 20 per cent sales tax is imposed on it. This tax will have a disastrous effect on the computer industry.

If the Opposition is genuine in what it says, it will support the Democrats' amendments which will oppose these three aspects of the sales tax legislation. I have heard members of the Opposition comment that they are a little uncertain about what they should do because they do not want to oppose a money Bill. We are not opposing the Bills outright. We are opposing only three aspects of them. What credibility can the Opposition possibly have if it is not prepared to join with us in supporting our amendments on these three aspects of the legislation, particularly when two of the taxes attack directly growers in the Murray Valley? In this case I refer to the wine tax, which is a tax on the grape growers of the Murray Valley, and to the tax on citrus growers. I note that Senator Messner is back in the chamber and I hope that he heard what I said a minute ago. I hope that the Opposition will retain some credibility and support the Democrats' amendments which will oppose only three aspects of the wholesale tax legislation. We are not opposing a money Bill; we are opposing three aspects of a new tax on three vitally important industries in this country-the wine industry, the citrus industry and the computer software industry.

I had occasion to visit the Murray Valley some few weeks ago where I addressed a meeting of some 600 citrus growers whose situation is absolutely desperate. Documented submissions carefully presented to the meeting of orange and citrus growers showed beyond any doubt that if citrus growers picked their fruit next year they would lose on a most conservative estimate $16,000 a grower. The Government is about to impose another 10 per cent tax on this industry which is facing a problem next year because of the depressed prices for orange juice on world markets and particularly on Australian markets. What sense does it make for the Government to impose another tax on an industry which is on its knees and hit it even harder? Senator Messner, who is well aware of that, instanced the situation of citrus growers and wine growers of South Australia. The growers in Victoria and New South Wales are equally in trouble. Surely the Opposition will do something to support this vital industry. I believe it would be absolutely irresponsible for this Senate to allow the Government to get away with imposing an additional 10 per cent tax on an industry that is going bankrupt, that is on its knees and that will, on the most conservative estimate, lose $16,000 a grower next year.

I have said that the 20 per cent tax on computer software will have a disastrous effect on the computer industry. This tax is in effect a tax on the transfer of information and is analogous to a tax on books. The Democrats opposed a tax on information in 1982 and we will certainly oppose this aspect of the sales tax legislation. Apart from anything else, one does not have to be very clever to see that it would be quite simple to get around the imposition of this tax by using various prices. In particular, it will be simple for multinational companies to get around the 20 per cent sales tax on computer software. However, we are concerned that this ineffective tax will apply to the local computer software industry.

Senator Messner mentioned at some length the fact that the wholesale tax is scheduled to raise $1.5 billion. This tax is a substitute for a broad-based consumption tax which the Democrats supported at the National Taxation Summit provided that it was not applied to the necessities of life. The Government chose not to go that way but rather to impose a revamped wholesale tax. We are opposed to that, and always have been, in principle. We are opposed because it is a cost on industry in this country. It is a very unpopular tax which presents difficulties in terms of equity. For all of those reasons we think it is a very bad second choice to a broad-based consumption tax. Nevertheless, that is the way the Government decided to go. The Democrats do not consider that we have the right to oppose outright the Government's taxing strategy. But we do have the right to attack the worst aspects of those taxation policies and that is what we have done in the case of the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax. This is what we are proposing to do right now in the case of this tax which will hit industries in a devastating way and will cause enormous hardships throughout Australia to say nothing of the inequity of the situation. We are importing tanker loads of orange juice from Brazil at subsidised prices. Australian growers cannot pick their oranges because if they do they will each lose $16,000 in the current year. At a time when this country is supposed to have a balance of payments problem and an enormous imbalance in its current account we are still financing the importation of tanker loads of Brazilian orange juice which is being subsidised to an enormous degree by the Brazilian Government and, I might add, indirectly by the United States Government. How unfair and how ridiculous this is. Surely something should be done about this situation.

I challenge the Opposition to do something about this legislation. It is all very well for members of the Opposition to say that they opposed the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax but that they will not do anything about this tax. At least they should be consistent. In this case we are talking about a rural industry which is as depressed as an industry can possibly be. Farmers who from 1945 to the present time, have spent a lifetime developing their blocks, who have spent days and night working up their farms, are now forced by the banks to sell. They are going bankrupt by the thousands, yet this Government is about to impose another tax.

How can the Opposition do other than support measures to stop the new tax being applied to such vital industries? I shall be very interested to hear what Senator Messner, and particularly the National Party, have to say in Committee about the tax imposts on the rural industry. Senator Bjelke-Petersen is to follow me in the debate. I shall be very interested to hear what she has to say. I hope that reason will prevail. I hope that the Opposition will take up the challenge.

I do not know how a member of the Liberal Party or a member of the National Party can ever again visit the Murray Valley if he does nothing to oppose these imposts. I can assure honourable senators that there was a long debate at the meeting which I addressed. The Opposition representatives were not prepared to commit themselves one way or another at that meeting. Senator Messner has not committed himself one way or another. Does he intend to support the Democrats in opposing the 10 per cent tax on fruit juice?

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you say?

—I said that representatives of the Opposition, including members of the National Party, were not prepared to commit themselves, in front of the growers in the Murray Valley, as to whether they would join with the Democrats in opposing the 10 per cent tax on fruit juice and the increased tax on wine.
—I will give my reasons later.

—Is the honourable senator going to allow the Government to get away with this? Is that what he is telling us? I can predict now that, if the Opposition supports the Government in imposing these taxes, it will be wasting its time going near the Murray Valley again. Feelings are running at white heat in that area of the world. If the Opposition thinks that it can talk its way out of supporting a new tax, when it could very easily join with the Demo- crats and block it-it could have circulated amendments of its own which we would have been happy to support-if it is going to sit back, do nothing and let the Government get away with it, what credibility can it possibly have? The Opposition talks about the present Government being the highest taxing government in our history. It talks about the way taxes have escalated. Yet it intends to sit back and let the Government get away with it. Where is the logic and the sense in that? How on earth members of the Opposition can hold up their heads and do that is beyond my comprehension. There is no consistency and concern for the very real problems of the people in the industries about which we are talking.

SPEECH.PARA: Two other Democrat senators wish to talk about the proposed tax measure, so I do not want to prolong my comments any longer than is absolutely necessary. However, it is a vital matter to the industry. It has always been a vital matter to the Democrats. We were not prepared to support a tax on the necessities of life in 1982 when that was used as an excuse to call a double dissolution. We will certainly not support a tax on the necessities of life in 1986. That is our basic and fundamental position. It is beyond comprehension that the Opposition can talk about the Government's taxing initiatives and let it get away with this measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1986 was introduced as part of the 1986-87 Budget, among other things, to increase the tax on alcoholic wine and cider and other similar fermented alcoholic beverages from 10 to 20 per cent, and to tax the previously exempt non-alcoholic beverages of flavoured milk and citrus juices, non-alcoholic wine and cider. The Opposition considers that this Bill, the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill and the Sales Tax Acts Amendment Bill are part of the Government's Budget Bills and, as such, the Opposition does not oppose them. However, that does not mean that the measures have our full support. Senator Siddons talked about how wicked it would be if we did not support the Australian Democrats' amendments to these Bills. I realise that the Democrats are very hypocritical in the way they talk about these Bills, because they did not support the Opposition when it wanted to vote against the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax. The Democrats now say, in a very pious way, that we should support their amendments against the sales tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition parties have indicated their position on the passage of the Bills. However, I wish to make some personal remarks about them. We are all quite used to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) making promises and pledges about what he `categorically and let me make this perfectly clear, unequivocally' will not do. We have seen many of those promises broken. It is nothing new. Of course, the same applies to this package of sales tax measures. The Prime Minister said that there would be no sales tax on wine, yet in last year's Budget a sales tax was introduced and, behold, in this year's Budget the tax has been raised from 10 per cent to 20 per cent.

Now we have a tax on good health. Yes, it finally had to happen. In this Labor Government's quest to tax just about everything that moves, we now have a tax on good health in the form of a 10 per cent tax on fruit juice and flavoured milk, both of which are enjoyed by people of all ages, but are particularly important for the health of our young children. I speak as a mother and particularly as a grandmother. This is an important matter. I wonder why any government would want to tax our children's good health. Citrus juices are a very convenient form of obtaining some extremely important vitamins. I realise that many citrus growers are having problems with imported orange juice. People have been in touch with me in that respect. However, we must realise, as must the Democrats, that the people of Australia voted the Australian Labor Party into office. The Labor Party has decided to impose a sales tax on such commodities as part of its Budget Bills and, unfortunately, I think that people will have to learn to live with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, why don't you join us in opposing it?

—Senator Siddons says that, in a very pious way, about the sales tax Bills, but he was quite happy to go along with introducing a fringe benefits tax. He was happy to go along with a capital gains tax. I feel that, in many ways, he is being very hypocritical. Flavoured milk is very often the only way that some children can be persuaded to drink milk at all. It certainly makes it a lot more palatable for children. I feel that it is ludicrous to tax something which is so good for young children. The human body needs protein, carbohydrate, calcium and a range of other minerals and vitamins. Milk is a valuable source of those.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year the Government decided to bring in a sales tax on ice cream. This year flavoured milk is the flavour of the month for the tax gatherers of Canberra. Next year, I suppose, it will be Vegemite sandwiches and Iced Vovos-some of the foods which children always enjoy. It is quite obvious that the Government is slowly but surely moving towards introducing indirect taxes on basic food items. Flavoured milk is a beverage which competes directly in the market-place with soft drinks. Whilst I do not wish to get myself into an argument, I think it is accepted that milk is the more nutritional food.

These Bills are also a blow to the dairy industry, which is experiencing some real problems. As a result of the dumping of surplus production by Northern Hemisphere producers, and in particular the European Community, Australian dairy producers are having difficulties in export markets. In recent months Parliament has been dealing with legislation affecting the dairy industry and the industry is still trying to sort itself out as a result. Why would this Government want to create further difficulties for dairy producers by taxing one of their most popular and most beneficial products?

I have received correspondence-I am sure other senators have also-from ITC (Australia), industry and trade consultants, on behalf of its client, Tetra Pak (Australia) Pty Ltd. ITC has advised me of a pilot program which has been framed to assess the viability of reintroducing milk to Australian primary schools, something I wholeheartedly support. I remind honourable senators that it was the very distinguished National Party Prime Minister, Sir Earle Page, who as Minister for Health in 1938 introduced free milk to primary school children. As a medical man Sir Earle realised the value of such a nutritionally sound food as milk and implemented a policy that all Australian school children should have a daily dose, as it were, to ensure that they had good bones and teeth. It was Mr Whitlam, I regret to say, who decided that free milk to school children was a waste of taxpayers' money. Now another Labor Government is deciding to impose a tax on flavoured milk. This 10 per cent tax on flavoured milk poses a serious threat to the introduction of a national program. In January 1986 Tetra Pak commenced the development of a pilot school milk program for children of primary school age. The rationale for this program was the perceived need to promote actively milk consumption in primary schools, keeping in mind that many children do not drink enough milk. I want to quote some information I received from Mr Graeme Day, the Director of ITC, who maintains:
Milk is essential as a source of nutrition during a child's growth. Without milk, children do not receive an adequate supply of calcium which is necessary for strong bones and teeth.

Mr Graeme Day gave a lot of information about the program, and I feel very sad that the proposed sales tax on milk may harm the program he is bringing forward. The sales tax imposed on fruit juices, drinks and cordials will have a similarly serious effect on the citrus industry. It will hinder not only citrus beverage producers but also fruit growers. It is not difficult to imagine the multiplier effect this will precipitate. Growers, packers, processors, freighters and juice manufacturers will all be affected, in the same way as they have been affected by the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the entertainment tax--

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you vote against them?

—We voted against them and we wanted the Democrats to vote against them too. If they had voted against those taxes the producers of citrus fruits would not be experiencing the problems they are at the present time. The increased freight and petrol costs are already harming the citrus industry, and this sales tax will harm even more not only the citrus industry but also our rural industries. The Government is anticipating about $50m to $60m will be collected through this new tax, but at what cost to the community associated with citrus growing? Mr Peter Wood, the General Manager of Berrivale Orchards Ltd, has told me that he is very upset about the proposed 10 per cent sales tax on juice beverages. In a letter to me-he probably sent it to all senators-he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Surely an estimated tax revenue of $37.9m on the `citrus' beverages cannot begin to cover the economic or social injustice that the cost of $245m will have on rural economies.

The tax imposition on flavoured milk and citrus juices in particular is very misguided. Besides the fact that the Government wants to raise additional revenue, the effects on local communities also have to be considered. I can see unemployment resulting from this decision, and once again it will be the non-metropolitan areas which will be hardest hit. The Government may have been advised that the imposts will have little or no effect on the industries concerned but I would have to disagree. Understanding the rural sector as I do, it is obvious that the tax will have a disastrous effect on the local communities involved with dairying and citrus growing.

The Democrats say that they will oppose sales tax on milk, citrus juices and wine despite the fact that it is part of the Budget Bills. I draw honourable senators attention to the fact that the Democrats did not hesitate to support the Government when it introduced the capital gains tax and the iniquitous fringe benefits tax. We all saw what happened in New South Wales where in the seat of Bass Hill there was a swing of 22 per cent against the Labor Party and in the seat of Rockdale there was a 17 per cent swing against Mr Barrie Unsworth, who had already been elected Premier of New South Wales. Mr Unsworth got in by only 57 votes. We know what will happen to the Labor Party and the Democrats in the Queensland election when voters realise that the Democrats were responsible, together with the Labor Party, for the introduction of these taxes. Dairy people, citrus growers and wine producers will remember this. The entertainment tax has already hit the wine industry in Queensland. The assets test and many other taxes have been imposed which could not have been introduced by the Government without the support of the Democrats. The Democrats are grandstanding when they talk about sales taxes on basic foodstuffs because they certainly let through many more infinitely worse taxes, as I have already outlined. The fact that the Government has allowed the economy to get in such a bad way that it has to tax children's food, such as milk and fruit juices, which provide vitamins, is appalling. I am not very happy about the way the Government has gone about the collection of these taxes. I certainly agree-

TALK.START.PARA: —To vote for them, yes.

—I have no intention of supporting the Democrats' amendments, which they have foreshadowed. I am very sorry indeed that the Government has decided to include taxes such as this as part of its money Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.28 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Australian Democrats' spokesperson on both primary industry and social security, I have a particular interest in speaking on the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill, which imposes a 10 per cent tax on a range of presently exempt products, including flavoured milk, non-alcoholic wine and cider and Australian fruit juice, and which increases the tax on wine from 10 to 20 per cent. It appeared that the Government decided to abandon the option of broadening the sales tax base at the end of the tax summit in July 1985. In the Government's paper on tax reform last year option C, the broad-based consumption tax, was to be introduced in conjunction with increased payments to social security beneficiaries and low income earners who would be disadvantaged if they had to spend more on the necessities of life-food, clothing, footwear and building materials-as a result of the imposition of a tax on those necessities.

SPEECH.PARA: In the 1986-87 Budget the Government decided to tax food-fruit juices and milk. In the same Budget it postponed the cost of living adjustments for those dependent on a whole range of social security payments and postponed measures designed to alleviate the poverty traps which are locking so many pensioners and beneficiaries into their situation below the poverty line. The Government has imposed a tax on food, yet there has been no compensatory income for low income earners. On the contrary, the Australian Labor Party has decided to reduce the disposable incomes of many Australians who are already living in poverty, by postponing the consumer price index adjustments and the implementation of the poverty traps legislation. So low income households get hit both ways-less income and more tax.

I wonder whether this is really what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) meant when he spoke of equitable distribution and of the sacrifices needed to get Australia out of its economic problems. The Liberal Party and the National Party are no better. They want to cut expenditure further. Those living in poverty are unlikely to get any comfort from the privatising Liberals who will slash billions of dollars from somewhere, but they will not say from where. The Liberals are not likely to reduce government assistance to the big business sector, banks, petrol companies and those who borrow billions of dollars overseas to reduce their tax liability in Australia. The Liberal Party and its coalition partner, the Nationals, will attack the Government for imposing these taxes on fruit juices, milk and wine. They have done so in this chamber today. If they meant what they said they could join us in opposing these measures and support our amendments.

I understand that Senator Vanstone is on record as being prepared to break ranks on one issue, the tax on wine, but that is not a significant act in terms of what is necessary in this area. This chamber can reject these taxes. It will not do so because the Liberals and Nationals who say that they oppose these measures are not prepared to oppose them by voting against them and preventing them becoming law. What is more, we really do not know why. Senator Messner, in responding to Senator Siddons's questions earlier, simply raised this evening's edition of the Melbourne Herald, which has a fairly prominent headline about an election before Christmas. Perhaps that is the reason of the Liberals and Nationals. Are they afraid of having an election before Christmas? Do they not want to be party to the blocking of legislation which might provide some sort of reason for the Government to call an election? Or is it just, as we have seen before, that they seem to be confused about the difference between a Budget Bill and a Supply Bill. Perhaps we should make it clear to them, as we have done before: Budget Bills are about raising money; Supply Bills are about spending money. There is a difference between raising money and spending money. If the Liberals and Nationals cannot tell the difference, we should all be afraid about an election before Christmas-considering the polls.

There may be a token floor-crossing in this exercise but it appears that the Liberals and Nationals will not join us in preventing these taxes from being implemented. They are prepared to privatise almost everything and to cut social security payments to those living in poverty. Yet they do not have the courage to vote against a tax on milk and orange juice. So much for their courage. So much for the farmer politicians who say that they really understand the problems of rural producers. Just two days ago in a rural provincial city in Victoria I was told by a journalist that she had been told by some of her local members of parliament, most of whom are farmer politicians, that farmers make the best parliamentarians because they know how to make decisions. This country having been led largely by farmer politicians in the decades post-World War II, if that is the case and they make the best politicians, why are our farmers now facing such a mess? This is happening because those farmer politicians could not see the writing on the wall.

In the 1960s the Common Market was not seen as a threat. As has been said: `He did but see her walking by and yet he loved her 'til she died'. It was thought that Britain would never do the dirty on Australia. So much for planning at the hands of farmer politicians. No, farmers do not necessarily make the best politicians. Even here in this chamber, on this day, they are not prepared to stand up for their electorates which rightly expect their support on these issues. In the past they have acted directly against the interests of their electorates which support them. In particular, I refer to the members of the National Party. In coalition with the Liberals they have joined with the Government so that we now have no effective income equalisation deposits scheme for people on the land, even though the Democrats stood firm. Again, through their joining with the Government increased export charges apply in a range of primary product areas. The Liberals and the Nationals will find that that part of their electorates will be much more sceptical.

The Liberals and Nationals will not support us in our amendments. They will not support Australian fruit juice producers who are already threatened by foreign products subsidised and dumped on the Australian market. They have turned their backs on dairy producers who are still coming to terms with the painful reality of rationalisation in the dairy industry. The Labor Party is responsible for introducing these taxes. I support tax increases on harmful products such as tobacco and on luxury products. We do not oppose taxes on luxury products in this legislation-the spas and swimming pools.

I find it difficult to support a tax on fruit juices and milk which, generally speaking, are nutritious and are bought by almost all Australian households, whether rich or poor. As I have said, these are taxes on the necessities of life, on food products which are consumed in considerable quantities by children. This imposes yet another burden on families which those on low incomes, and especially those living below the poverty line, can ill afford-households which, I remind the Senate, include 800,000 children. To be realistic, we could not have expected those in a Liberal-National coalition to take up the cause of the poor or low income families, but at the very least it might have been the expectation of a very large part of what they consider to be their electorates that the coalition would have supported them in this matter.

Those people who live in rural Australia producing milk and fruit, those living in country towns servicing those producers and those working in the related processing industries would have thought that at least they would get support on these measures through support for the Democrat amendments to come. Only the Australian Democrats are prepared to stand firm on principles. We have opposed sales taxes on the necessities of life and will continue to do so. We have opposed legislation which does not support our very strong interests in the need to support our vital rural industries and we will continue to do so. I repeat: It is anomalous of a government which reduces the incomes of people already on low incomes and below the poverty line to introduce a broad-based sales tax at the same time as it is expecting this Parliament to pass legislation which further reduces the incomes of those groups.
