SPEECH.PARA: The burden of the speech we have just heard was basically that there should be a bigger deficit, that there should be no taxes. The Democrats have already given an indication that they think $6 billion is not a bad sized deficit. They continually talk about getting rid of taxes and complain about government spending being cut. What sort of an economy do these people want? The answer clearly is this: Everything they have said points to an economy where interest rates would soar, where the Government would be obliged to borrow more, where the whole thrust of policies, certainly those which the Opposition has been strongly pressing, would be reversed, and they are the policies of responsibility, of restraint and of preventing this economy going down the gurgler. We have complained for years about the reckless behaviour of the Government. I have to say this in the Government's defence: It almost looks respectable compared with the Australian Democrats; but only almost. Here we have the most irresponsible ratbag organisation that has graced this chamber, which is opposed to everything that would involve any political disfavour but which would grab anything upon which it could build its hope that it will achieve some momentary support of an electoral nature. These political opportunists, who know they will never have to live with the consequences of what they are doing and saying, come here and act out this self-righteous charade in this place as if they were people who should be taken seriously.

As honourable senators know, the Australian Democrats have very little chance of survival unless there is a double dissolution. They have no prospect of getting more than the 14 per cent quota that is required in a half Senate election, and yet in some States they have two people coming up for election. Clearly the only way that they can get one person elected, let alone two, is to have a double dissolution. I would not back their chances of getting one person elected in most States; in fact, one could almost say in all States, in view of the incredible and evident opportunism that is now being revealed by their undisguised self-interest in their approach to legislation, particularly this Bill, the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill, and allied Bills now before the Senate.

I would very much like to reinforce and support all the points that were made by Senator Messner in expressing our concern and opposition to these unfortunate sales taxes which will have a serious effect on the industries concerned. We do not deny that. That is one part of what the Democrats are saying that we agree with: This legislation will have an unfortunate effect, just as the fringe benefits tax, which they supported, had an unfortunate effect-we use the word `unfortunate' there in its most peripheral sense-a disastrous effect.

Let us recognise the reality. The Senate has the capacity to defeat this Budget Bill, as has been stated here by the Australian Democrats. However, we do not have the capacity to cut government spending. In other words, the only capacity we have is the capacity to increase the deficit, to increase the amount of money the Government would have to borrow, to increase the Government's impact on interest rates, to push up interest rates affecting the whole nation-affecting home buyers, manufacturers and employers of people. This is the sort of policy that the Australian Democrats clearly favour by grasping at this particular straw of self-interest. We take the view that no matter how wrong we believe the Government's Budget to be-and we believe it to be very significantly wrong basically because it has not cut government spending-it would be totally irresponsible for us, as we have no power to cut government spending, at the same time to reduce the Government's income and thereby increase the deficit, as that would have a disastrous impact on the whole of Australia. Although I say that the Government has not cut its spending, we have seen immense propaganda that it has. The Government has continually talked about spending cuts. Let me assure the Senate that there has been no such thing. This Government increased its spending by $4.8 billion in the current Budget-that is, by 6.9 per cent. After that has been adjusted for inflation, it is still a record level. The so-called Budget cuts are simply cuts in what the Government wanted to spend by continuing the hugely increased spending programs that it had introduced over the previous three Budgets. In its first Budget the Government increased spending on its own new programs by something like $2 1/2 billion; it was another $1.3 billion, I think, in the second Budget, and so on. The cuts were simply a continuation of its programs that had been expanded in this irresponsible and reckless way-almost an Australian Democrats way. The cut is simply on what that spending would have been for this year had it not pulled its horns in a little.

As for cuts in spending, there are none this year. Spending is going up by a record level. The people who will have to pay for that irresponsibility, for the Government's lack of concern and lack of preparedness to do what is right for Australia, are the people who will be paying this tax, the people who will be paying the fringe benefits tax, the people who will be paying this whole range of taxes which this year is increasing the tax burden on Australians to the highest level in real terms on record. That is despite the so-called tax cuts that are coming later this year. Despite those tax cuts, the taxes ordinary Australians will have to pay will rise to record levels. If the Government can deny that, I would like to hear it do so. We have not heard that denial yet. There is not much point in asking the Democrats to make a coherent comment, so I will not ask them to deny it.

We face the reality of having no option, if we are a responsible opposition, but to accept this dreadful Budget. I can only urge the Australian Democrats to cease playing politics on this matter. That does not exclude the fact that there are many unexpected disadvantages, if I could use those words. What was the phrase the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) used today in the other House about the consequences of the fringe benefits tax?

TALK.START.PARA: —Unintended effects.

—Yes, unintended effects. The Prime Minister today, having been bombarded by the Opposition ever since this tax was announced in the Budget with the inevitability of disaster in what is basically a bad tax imposed in a bad way and having bad consequences, finally admitted that there are these unintended consequences and that the Government would look at it. Let me tell the Government that I trust the disastrous consequences of the sales tax rise are also unintended. If they are so unintended, maybe the Prime Minister and the Government should have another look at this as well. If it is good enough for the Government to have another look at the fringe benefits tax and its unintended consequences because there is an election in Queensland-and we hear rumours of a Federal election perhaps at the end of this year-how about it having a look at the unintended consequences of these sales tax rises? I use the word `unintended' almost in inverted commas because I frankly do not believe that it is unintended. I think this Government has set out on this course for a whole curious range of reasons. I believe that the Government is still basically against the small businessman. I think this Government sees the small businessman as a threat-it is not simply the socialist ideal of having the State looking after everyone-to the cosy coalition of big business, big government and big unions that this nation is now being governed by.
—Big opposition.

—I think it is big foot in big mouth over on Senator Vigor's side. I believe that this Government has no concern or interest in small business but in fact has strong hostility towards its very principles, its very procedures-its whole atmosphere of small business. Individual entrepreneurs who are not the business bureaucrats, the governmental bureaucrats or the union bureaucrats but are the real people of Australia, want to have a go. They are the sort of people that this tax specifically hits, just as the fringe benefits tax specifically hits a whole range of middle Australians, not the rich people whom the Government keeps talking about, but the many people who eat their lunches out of Mr Keating's brown paper bags. I would be interested to consider the last time Mr Keating ate his lunch out of a brown paper bag. God knows what else he receives in brown paper bags, but it is not his lunch.

SPEECH.PARA: I would now like to deal with other matters in this sales tax legislation in terms of the unintended consequences. We wonder whether the unintended consequence relating to the computer industry has been recognised by the Government. I doubt it. There is no doubt that a tax of a quite discriminatory nature has been introduced on services provided in the computer industry. In particular, it discriminates against Australian operators in the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—I am glad to hear Senator Vigor say `Hear, hear' because among the things I respect concerning him is his knowledge of the computer industry.
—He has got more to respect than most of them, too.

—Yes. What intrigues me is that Senator Vigor, who has some knowledge of this matter, is so little regarded by his colleagues that he has been put in an unwinnable position on the South Australian ticket. That probably reflects, quite properly and quite reasonably, the sorts of priorities the Australian Democrats have. They are not concerned with having anyone with competence or knowledge in particular areas in this place and as a result they are banishing him to an unwinnable position. I have no difficulty in commending him on his knowledge of this area and regret that that knowledge will soon no longer be available to us. On the other hand, I do not regret that the presence of his colleagues will not be with us much longer either. Nevertheless, the question of computers is quite interesting. A long letter in the Age newspaper a couple of weeks ago dealt with this situation at some length. I regret to say that I did not ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) whether I could incorporate this letter in Hansard but it would save me reading it. I would be grateful if the Minister, after having looked at it, would give me leave to have it incorporated.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Keating plays a game that he alone can win
from Mr Darryl Hubbard,
Sandhurst Computer Services
Has Mr Keating stumbled upon the ``ultimate computer game'' with his sales tax on the ``manufacture'' of computer software?
STRIP-Sales Tax Rip-off of Intellectual Property-seems to be a winner-takes-all game with Mr Keating never losing.

According to a representative of the Melbourne sales tax office, a computer program will be deemed to have been manufactured when it is transferred from RAM (random-access-memory) to a storage medium such as tape or disk.
Consequently, when a programmer entrusts the products of his intellectual processes to magnetic immortality, Mr Keating scores with STRIP.

As it may take many tries for the programmer successfully to transfer the computer program, Australia's computers will resemble video STRIP poker machines with tax money pouring out to mark a successful compilation.
Perhaps the State governments will require that computers be registered-but then it is not gambling, it's sure money!

Who must pay the sales tax? The manufacturer (i.e., programmer) according to the sales tax office representative, except when the programmer is an employee of a company which intends to use the computer software ``in house''.
Where the computer consultant is an independent consultant, he must be registered as a manufacturer of computer software and, hence, is required to pay sales tax.
Now we have an interesting problem when two programmers are working on a computer program for the same company, one an employee of the company, the other a consultant.

Given that the ``Event'' of the manufacture occurs when the program is transferred from RAM to disk, does the liability of sales tax fall on the person who presses the key to initiate the process which ``manufactures'' the computer program?
In future the computer consultant will be able not only to write computer programs but also to play STRIP with Mr Keating.
Is this all fair?
Consider the situation of the computer consultant with an income of $36,000 from a year spent ``manufacturing'' computer programs.
He must give Mr Keating $6000 sales tax and, on the remaining $30,000, pay $8612 income tax-a total tax contribution of $14,612.
A programmer employed by a company could also earn $36,000 in a year spent similarly and pay a total of $11,525 income tax.
Therefore, the computer consultant pays 27 per cent more tax for the same work.
Of course Mr Keating would astutely advise that the consultant charge the client an extra $7200 sales tax in order to maintain his gross income of $36,000.
Now the consultant will contribute $18,725 in tax to Mr Keating, which represents 62 per cent more tax for the same work-a much higher score.
What is the situation if the company for whom the consultant works will not pay another $7200 for the consultant to score for Mr Keating?
The first result is that his income is reduced immediately by 20 per cent.
Alternatively, he could be offered temporary employment to manufacture the computer program and, hence, the sales tax is avoided.
Or is it? Could both the company and the consultant be caught by the catch-all tax legislation and give Mr Keating an even larger jackpot with extra penalty points being added to the original score.
Perhaps Mr Keating could answer these questions for me.

Are computer programmers only the first victims of STRIP? What about lawyers, accountants, journalists and others who use their intellects to ``Manufacture'' written advice to their clients via computer in the form of a word processor?

Mr Keating's coup de grace would be to require a sales tax chip to be fitted to all computers to record every RAM to disk manufacturing process so that sales tax can be calculated exactly and accurately, preferably combined with a point-of-sales tax terminal to provide an automatic funds transfer to Mr Keating's STRIP score.
DARRYL HUBBARD
Bendigo

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. The detail I want to go into on this matter of professional services is that many Australian computer firms sell directly at retail. They do not have a wholesale price. When they sell directly at retail, because they do not operate through wholesalers, there is no wholesale price on which the sales tax can be calculated. As I understand it, the Australian computer companies in this situation have approached the Australian Taxation Office and the Treasurer and said: `For heaven's sake can't we have an imputed wholesale price against which the sales tax can be assessed rather than having it assessed on the only price available which is the retail price?'. The Taxation Office has, I understand, said: `No, that cannot be done'. This is incredible. It means that if an international group such as IBM brings in some software from the United States of America at a wholesale price of say $50,000 with a retail price of say $100,000 it will pay sales tax at the wholesale price, which is 20 per cent on $50,000. Yet if an Australian manufacturer gets the contract, he has to pay sales tax at the only price available which is the retail price-let us say it is exactly the same as IBM's-of $100,000. In other words, the client of the Australian company in this case would have to pay $120,000 for exactly the same equipment he could buy from a multinational company, for example, which might have imported it for $110,000. The Government is having another unintended impact, an unintended effect, because of the way this legislation will operate.
—It is worse than that because IBM can get away with bringing its software in as an aid to manufacture.

—Exactly. I thank Senator Vigor for his point. It brings me to the next interesting point about anomalies. Under the legislation there is also the absurdity that if a consultant advises a company that its software program should be rewritten and if the company follows that advice, the consultant's fee is taxable, as I understand it. Because the advice has led to a change of software, the consultant's fee is part of the change and is therefore subject to a 20 per cent sales tax. How a consultant can properly quote a fee for his consultancy without knowing whether or not at the end of it there will be a change in the software program heaven alone knows-or rather heaven and the Commissioner of Taxation, because he appears to regard himself as interchangeable with heaven.
—It is the other place.

—I take that point, too. The reality is that if, as a result of a consultancy, there is a change in software the whole consultancy is subject to sales tax. All one has to do to avoid that is not to have the consultant do it, to have the company do it in house. One might ask: Why not have that done? It could be done by a big company with the capacity to do so. Once again the person being belted by this ludicrous legislation is the small businessman whose business does not have the capacity to do it and who must employ a consultant to do the job. So we have a succession of ludicrous anomalies, anomalies which have been brought to the attention of the Government. As I have demonstrated, there have been letters to the newspapers pointing out the unfairness of the situation. Yet this Government, simply because it has not felt the need to respond to the pressure it has had on the fringe benefits tax-in other words, because it does not see the same political need-is not now making the expedient changes in this area which it is prepared to make to the fringe benefits tax. I suggest to the Government that many of these areas deserve to be considered.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Messner said, it is incredible that at a time of vine pull in South Australia the Government is belting the wine industry again, an industry which is under such heavy pressure. There is the dairy industry, and the imposition of a sales tax on flavoured milk. This is ludicrous. Who would suggest that the dairy industry is in a healthy situation? As I understand it, dumping by Brazil is very badly affecting the orange juice industry. It is not simply the taxes this Government is introducing; the Government's timing compounds the problem. There is no doubt in my mind that the case against these taxes is overwhelming, provided the offset is a reduction in government spending. I would be overjoyed at the prospect of getting rid of these taxes if at the same time we could get rid of the government spending that the taxes are paying for. As I have said, we do not have the capacity in opposition to impose on the Government the sort of discipline, self-restraint or responsibility it keeps talking about but never practises-this big spending Government.

It would be totally irresponsible of us, in attacking this Budget, to do anything to increase the deficit. We have consistently and responsibly and I believe credibly argued that the main task this Government has is to reduce its demands on Australians, to get off Australians' backs. The only way it can do that is by cutting government spending. Yet tonight we have heard once again the people who allowed the fringe benefits tax legislation to go through, the Australian Democrats, who supported the Government at the time, calling for the cutting of government revenue and the increasing of government spending-the classic irresponsibility. I do not believe that it would be right or in Australia's interests for the Opposition to be as opportunist as the Australian Democrats. We are far more responsible. Under the proposals of the Australian Democrats Australia would suffer even more in terms of falling investment, rising unemployment and the worsening of the current account deficit, which this Budget expects. So, no matter how strongly we oppose these taxes-as we do; we think the consequences will be most unfortunate in some areas and almost as severe in some areas as the consequences of the fringe benefits tax which the Democrats support-we believe that in terms of responsibility and credibility we cannot vote against them unless we can reduce government spending equally. In those circumstances I suggest to the Australian Democrats that they stop playing politics and thinking of their prospects of survival at a double dissolution and start thinking about the whole of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a rather extraordinary speech from an honourable senator who quite clearly can find no real justification or any rational argument for the odd stance the Opposition parties are taking in supporting the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1986, the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1986 and the Sales Tax Acts Amendment Bill 1986, and who therefore had to spend something like half his speech abusing the Australian Democrats. In doing so he made a number of rather contradictory statements. He alleged, for example, that the only reason the Democrats were opposing this legislation and supporting the industries that are to be affected by the legislation was so that we could avoid political disfavour. He said that a sentence or two after he had accused us of all sorts of political chicanery and rejection of what was in the best interests of industry and commerce by failing to oppose the fringe benefits tax. I would have thought that if we were in the game of avoiding political disfavour-and Senator Michael Baume thinks there is a tremendous amount of odium attached to supporting the fringe benefits tax-surely we would have joined the Opposition in voting against the fringe benefits tax. If we had joined the Opposition in voting against the fringe benefits tax we would have denied this Government access to something like $370m, or some 10 times the amount that would be denied to this Government by not going along with the legislation before us.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that the fringe benefits tax legislation was not a Budget measure does not mean that it was not real money the Government was trying to raise from the fringe benefits tax. Money is money and revenue is revenue, whether it is raised by a Bill which is introduced between August and November or a Bill which is introduced between February and June. If Opposition senators are going to divide artificially the legislation we consider in this place into those two parts of the year, then I suggest that they all vacate the premises between August and November and go back to their electorates, where there is some chance of them doing some good-although I doubt it-and possibly earning the money they are paid.

The trick that they have been trying to pull for so long on so many people in the com- munity-that Budget Bills are somehow sacrosanct and somehow linked with Supply-is simply not washing any longer. Their credibility in areas such as the Riverland in South Australia, in Mildura and elsewhere, is nil. The National Farmers Federation in that area, the United Farmers and Stockowners of South Australia, and equivalent organisations in other States, have sought independent advice about what the constitutional role and rights of the Senate are. They have been told what I have been telling them for some time. Any piece of legislation which is defeated twice, with a period of three months in between, provides grounds for a double dissolution. But that dissolution is called at the Government's discretion, as Malcolm Fraser proved in his last years in office. The only thing that forces a government to call a double dissolution is if Supply is blocked, as it was in 1975, and that is not likely to happen in this chamber again-at least while we have any say in the matter.

Senator Michael Baume and his colleagues can stop trying to continue this farcical argument that there is something sacrosanct about Budget Bills and that the country will fall into a bigger hole in the ground than it is already in if we defeat one or two of them. That is not the case, and we proved that in 1981 when we amended the Fraser Government's sales tax legislation by removing from it reference to the necessities of life. I understand that that cost the Government in the vicinity of $250m, if the then Minister for Finance was to be believed. While it was certainly used for the calling of a double dissolution 15 months later, it was simply a device. The government of the day did not fight the election on the question of the sales tax on the necessities of life, nor should it have, of course. But it was defeated in any event.

If Senator Michael Baume wants to run the rather puerile argument that the only reason that we are opposing this legislation is that we want a double dissolution because it is in our political interests, I point out again that in 1981, when we amended the Fraser Government's sales tax legislation in a similar way to the way in which we want to amend this legislation, three of the five senators of the Australian Democrats that year were five months into six-year terms. We had every justification then, if we wanted to play pragmatic and opportunistic politics, simply to sit on our hands and wait until our turn came around again. We chose not to because, as far as we are concerned, whether legislation is introduced in August-September, February-March or some other time, it ought to be looked at on its merits. One ought to consult the people involved and act accordingly, and not spread some sort of specious story around the community that one somehow cannot do it. That is political cowardice of the worst sort.

I point out to Senator Michael Baume and his colleagues that there is not much point in setting up a wine industry action group to look into an industry that may not exist by the middle of next year. That fact is made perfectly clear by the submission that was put out by the Australian Wine and Brandy Producers' Association which, amongst other things stated:
The Australian wine industry is facing a crisis.

The biggest crisis it is facing, of course, is having this lot in opposition instead of having them out of the place altogether, replaced by a group of people who are prepared to care for industries and the people who are employed by the industries that they see as part of their constituency. The Association continued:
The sales of Australian wine are stagnating; stocks remain high and prices are depressed.
It is not just the wine prices that are depressed, either. The submission continues:

Wine producers have largely absorbed the 10% sales tax on wine to maintain sales throughput and cash flow. The intended tax on consumers has therefore been a tax on wine producers/retailers. Many wine producers are on a fine edge of viability. Any additional pressure on wine sales or erosion of wine producers profit margins will force these producers out of business.

So I imagine that whatever committee has been set up, calling itself the wine industry action group, will not have a very difficult task. There will not be a very large wine industry to look at. It will comprise largely the boutique wineries and the very large conglomerates, both of which are likely to survive this additional hike in sales tax. The boutique wineries will survive because they make small and selected products and the purchasers of those products are prepared to pay pretty much whatever the producer asks. The larger wineries will survive because they will simply narrow the range of their products, so that they can cut their production costs. It is the middle-of the-the-range wineries, the sort of wineries that we see in the Riverland in South Australia, that will suffer, and when they suffer, the growers suffer. When the growers suffer, the entire area suffers. An area such as the Riverland is dependent very much on wine production and on citrus fruit products, which is the second of the areas that we are particularly concerned about. This legislation is hitting very hard a number of industries and a number of areas which Liberal and National Party senators have been telling us for years comprise the bulk of their constituencies. These people are now starting to wake up to what the Opposition's little game is all about.

The other problem of an area such as the Riverland in South Australia is that those people who are involved in citrus growing are also vine growers in many cases. As both of those areas are being hit in these Bills, there is no way that they can offset the losses that they are likely to suffer. So a number of towns in the Riverland of South Australia will have increasing numbers of families who are reliant on social welfare benefits of some sort, with a consequent impact not only on their standard of living and self esteem, but also on other small businesses in the area. When one cuts the disposable incomes of large numbers of families in a small area such as the Riverland, the impact on local small businesses is tremendous. I do not think it is going too far to say that the entire area could become poverty stricken in no time at all.

With regard to the tax on fruit juices and milk, as my colleague Senator Powell said earlier, these are taxes on foodstuffs and are particularly stupid for a number of reasons. The flavoured milk sector of the dairy industry is one of the few growth areas that that industry has. As far as fruit juice is concerned, the Government is putting a 10 per cent tax on pure fruit juice at the same time as it has referred the problems of that industry to the Industries Assistance Commission. If the Government is prepared to accept that citrus fruit growers are having sufficient problems to warrant an inquiry by the IAC, why is it pulling the plug thoroughly on these people and allowing them to go down the gurgler in this way? They are already suffering from what is essentially the dumping of Brazilian orange juice in Australia, orange juice which, unfortunately and unfairly, is made competitive with the Australian product because of subsidisation of that industry by the Brazilian Government. It is ridiculous that, in addition, Brazil should also receive developing nation preferential tariff treatment in this country. It seems to me that this Government, with a little help from the Opposition, is doing its damnedest to destroy a number of extremely efficient Australian industries at a time when it should be propping them up. At a time when it is talking about buying Australian, for goodness sake, it is attempting to pull the plug on a number of first-class Australian industries.

The proposed 10 per cent tax on fruit juice and milk is unquestionably a tax on food and, as Senator Powell said earlier, on food which is traditionally regarded as important in the growth and development of children. One wonders whether this is not merely the thin edge of the wedge and whether we will see next a tax on bread and fresh vegetables in an attempt by this Government to raise revenue from whatever sources it can whilst, I might add, ignoring the fact that there are some extremely wealthy entrepreneurs in this country who are entitled to negatively gear on overseas financed money used for some very unproductive takeovers in this country.

As I said, the citrus fruit growers are already hard hit by the large volume of heavily subsidised imported juice from Brazil. The wine tax, which is a doubling of the impost already placed on that industry, is a tax on one of the up and coming export areas we have in this country. At a time when our balance of trade is as bad as it is, I see no reason why this Government or the Opposition should assist in hammering the last nail in the industry's coffin. The small amount of revenue that is to be raised by this legislation cannot justify the action on the part of this Government or the two-faced behaviour on the part of the Opposition. For the Opposition to argue that it cannot challenge this legislation and will not oppose it, simply because the Government needs this revenue in order to keep its deficit down, ignores the fact that the Opposition parties voted against two other measures that would have raised substantially more money-the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax.

As I said earlier, whether those are Budget Bills or not, they are revenue raising Bills, and the Opposition knows it. The money is still coming in, no matter where it is coming from. I think that the Opposition needs to come up with either more rational arguments for supporting the legislation or it ought honestly to admit that it supports the taxes on these products-that it is hoping and, indeed, planning to benefit from the taxes on these products should it ever get back into government-and at least earn the respect, if not the support, of the people who it is damaging in supporting these iniquitous pieces of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1986 quite obviously deals with some changes to the imposition of sales taxes on a variety of products in Australia. I have a particular concern with one product affected by this Bill. The particular concern I have is with the effect this Bill will have on the wine industry-an industry which is more strongly represented in South Australia than in any other State. I will deal with my concerns with respect to the wine industry first. In 1983 the Australian Labor Party promised that it would not introduce a wine tax. Not long after that it introduced a 10 per cent sales tax on wine. At the same time the reduction in differential between domestic and imported wine was introduced. Following that we had the fringe benefits tax and the entertainment tax, both of which substantially affect the wine industry and both of which were supported by the Australian Democrats. Now we have effectively the doubling of this sales tax on the wine industry. We have this doubling despite the recommendations of the Government's own study into the wine industry.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, this particular sales tax very much affects South Australia. We produce 57.5 per cent of Australia's wine. Quite obviously we produce more, therefore, than any other State. This tax will affect a wide variety of people. I have heard some people say that it will particularly affect the big wine companies, the conglomerates, and that they can afford to pay. But what the people who say that sort of thing forget is simply this: They forget or ignore the employees of those companies who may well be dismissed in the interests of efficiency. They forget or ignore the small wine makers and their employees. They forget or ignore the grape growers and they forget or ignore the people with jobs in retailing and marketing of wine. They are the sorts of people who will be affected by this tax.

As I pointed out, my State will be affected by this tax more than any other State. The effect on my State will be very broadly spread. It will be spread right across the State from Coonawarra down in the south east to the Barossa Valley, the Clare Valley, the McLaren Vale area and the Riverland area, which will be particularly hard hit by this tax because it is also an area which produces citrus juice and which is affected by another aspect of this legislation. It will also affect the wine makers and grape growers on the Adelaide Plains.

This tax will not only affect my State more than any other State but also its effect will spread very broadly across my State. I believe that it is an ill-considered tax. It is common knowledge within the industry and in fact amongst members of this chamber and of the lower House that this was a last minute tax. Rumours in the industry are that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) did not really want this tax but he was informed at the last minute, euphemistically speaking, by the Treasury that this tax was to be imposed. Our Treasurer (Mr Keating)-the Labor Treasurer; I do not want to call him my Treasurer-told all Australians that he wanted well planned tax reform. The doubling of this wine tax at the last minute is no indication of his capacity in any way whatsoever to introduce well planned tax reform. What this tax represents is a last minute grab at an industry that is predominantly South Australian. In the population sense we are a relatively small State. We provide only 13 Federal seats in the House of Representatives. Federal Government is not won or lost in South Australia. A relatively small swing will not affect the distribution of seats between the major parties in South Australia. On the other hand, a relatively small swing in the eastern States may well change the Government. That, of course, is the very reason for this chamber coming into being.

Given the effect of this particular tax and the doubling of the wine tax that I have outlined, I asked myself: What does the Labor Premier of my State, Mr Bannon, intend to do? It is a very short answer, of course. He intends to do virtually nothing. I am told that he admitted in a somewhat embarrassed tone-I would be embarrassed if I were he-to a meeting of wine industry representatives that he would not come to Canberra and be humiliated by the Treasurer. That is okay. If he is too weak to make these representations, that is his problem. But what about Mr Bannon's own backyard, the area where Mr Bannon has the power to do something? What is he doing in South Australia to assist this industry? The answer is, nothing. Mr Bannon, the Premier of the Labor Government in South Australia, stands to collect an enormous windfall from the increase in licence fees-a tax on a tax. At least Mr Bannon could return this in some way to the wine industry in his State, but what do we hear? Nothing; silence.

I strongly disapprove of other matters dealt with in this Bill; not the least of these is the imposition of a tax on 100 per cent fruit juice and also the tax on flavoured milk. I agree with my colleagues with respect to the effect that these taxes, and for that matter the wine tax, will have on the respective industries. But these matters will not affect my State to the same degree as the doubling of the wine tax. South Australia produces 57.5 per cent of Australia's wine and thus this tax hits my State proportionately much harder than any other State.

The Australian Democrats have made much tonight of their shopping list which is designed to woo votes from sectional interests. They do so knowing that they have no chance of ever being in government, no chance of ever being in the position of having to put their promises into practice. There is no chance of ever letting the electorate see whether the party which says that it is here to keep the so-called bastards honest-and that is the remainder of us in the chamber-would, if it were in government, practise what it preaches. I submit that if ever such a misfortune were to befall this country we would find that the Democrats would not practise what they preach. In fact, quite the opposite would be the case. You, Mr Deputy President, would be well aware of the number of times that in this chamber we have tried to get pieces of legislation referred to respective committees. The Australian Democrats have a policy that legislation should be scrutinised by committees. Where has the support of the Democrats been when we have given them the opportunity to put their policy into practice? Their support for putting their policy into practice has been right out the door.

But enough of the Democrats. One can devote only so much of one's speech to the likes of the Democrats. I wish to return to the wine tax. I am conscious of the bipartisan call from my State Parliament against this tax. The announcement by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) of a wine industry study group is, I believe, a positive contribution to the development of a long term policy for this important industry, not just for my State but for all of Australia. As a member of that group, I look forward to working towards the resolution of the industry's problems. As Senator Messner pointed out earlier this evening, the problems of the wine industry go well beyond this tax. All of those problems, including this tax, require urgent and serious attention. They need to be dealt with in a comprehensive manner so that we can understand how different policy aspects interrelate. In other words, we want a co-ordinated approach to this industry.

Despite Labor grandstanding in the South Australian Parliament, Labor members and senators in Canberra have not spoken out to defend their State's clearly identified interest as the Liberals have done here tonight. I accept the Opposition's general response to the Budget. This is a Labor Budget and the Labor Government is responsible for the harsh consequences it creates for many Australians. That is true, and I will continue to promote that view. However, senators are elected, amongst other things, to represent their States. The Liberal Party firmly believes that an upper House is a necessary element in our Federal parliamentary system. Unlike the Labor Party, Liberals are proud of the independence we give to our parliamentary members. What it amounts to is that in the final analysis we must each be responsible for the decisions we make. As a member of the States House, I believe I have an obligation to take a stand for South Australia and demonstrate in the forum to which I have been elected-namely, this chamber-my opposition to this tax. Accordingly, with some regrets, I will support the amendment to remove clause 5 (2), which effectively doubles this tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vanstone, the previous speaker in the debate, made a point which, from my point of view in terms of parliamentary democracy, I found very odd. She made the accusation that one in fact would not be respon- sible for something or other unless one were actually in government. Quite frankly, I have always rejected that extraordinary view. Quite frankly, I find it an extraordinary statement and one of the most incredible and worst types of accusations that anyone could make in this place that other senators were in fact willing to vote one way or another without taking any responsibility for their actions. For some reason the odd political philosophy has become perpetrated in Australia that parliamentarians are not responsible for legislation. It so happens that for the majority of the time since Federation governments have in fact not controlled this chamber. Hence, for a majority of the time this chamber has made or broken various pieces of legislation.

Quite frankly, I am quite happy in terms of the job that I do to remain a senator. It is a job to which I believe everybody in this country would aspire. It is an incredibly responsible job. It has spoken at great length about how disastrous the imposition of a new tax will be on the wine growers, the wine industry, in the Murray Valley; yet it is not prepared to do anything about it. During hours of debate we have heard that the industry is going through bad times, that it is going through a shake-out period, and yet at that very time the Government has introduced an additional 10 per cent tax. The Opposition is not prepared to do anything about it. It simply says: `Oh, this is a Budget Bill'. The logic is incredible.

The Opposition has accused the Australian Democrats of not being prepared to join it in opposing the introduction of the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax, although we moved very substantial amendments in both cases. We saved the car industry $200m in respect of the fringe benefits tax. We moved 16 amendments to the capital gains tax legislation. We adopt the attitude that, as a responsible opposition, we should not fundamentally attempt to block Government initiatives. However, as a responsible opposition, we should amend the worst aspects of the Government's legislative program. We did that in the case of the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax, and we are asking the Opposition to join us and do it again in the case of this enormously vicious tax on an industry that is already on its knees-the wine industry of the Murray Valley.

It is not possible to understand how the Opposition could not support us in our amendments. We can only imagine that it is not doing so because of some deal worked out between the laborials behind closed doors. TALK.START.PARA: —First and foremost, let me deal with two or three points raised by Senator Siddons. SPEECH.PARA: Let us address ourselves to the question of Budget legislation. We in the Liberal and National parties have a very clear view about that. The Government is entitled to its Budget. That means that in seeking to run its financial affairs it is entitled, when it brings down its Budget, to have the passage of both its taxation legislation and other spending legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Vanstone?

—She has to make up her own mind about that matter. These are the decisions that have been made in the Liberal and National parties' party room. The position is simple. In the event of legislation being in the normal form and not of an outrageous character, such as retrospective legislation and so on, we have an obligation not to oppose the Government's legislation. Clearly that is the decision of the Liberal and National parties and has been our position for some time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats make the point that somehow opposing this measure is the same as opposing the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax. Nothing could be further from the truth because neither of those taxes were Budget matters. They were brought down in a hotch-potch fashion about a year ago. The Government struggled manfully through the next nine months to prepare legislation of which we saw nothing until it finally appeared in the House last May and was rushed through this place at a great rate of knots. Of course we are now suffering all the effects of that legislation. Female employees going home from shift work at night will be under all kinds of pressure because the Government will force employers to pay the fringe benefits tax on the fares for taxis provided for female employees in that situation. Gold watches will be taxed when they are eventually handed out to long term employees of a company who retire. Domestic help for crippled people at home will be subject to the fringe benefits tax. Guess who has brought us these great benefits? None other than the Democrats, none other than Senator Siddons, have brought us these magnificent pieces of legislation which we oppose strongly. However, that is not the point I want to make.

The point is this: Senator Siddons makes out that somehow this tax is connected to the Budget of the Government. I recall very well that during debates on this legislation in the Senate only last May Senator Siddons said that the Government would not be able to give people their tax cuts unless we passed the legislation for a capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax. The legislation has nothing to do with the deficit. By the admission of the Democrats, it is to do with providing people with tax cuts and it has nothing to do with the Budget or its deficit. That is the essential point we make.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! We are discussing an amendment on orange juice. I ask you to keep to the matter before us.

—I thought the matter was highly relevant. However, I think I have made that point. The next thing that is obviously necessary for the wine industry in South Australia and in all other parts of Australia is stability. What this industry has been subject to for the last seven or eight years-I extend this to the period of the brandy excise introduced in 1978-is the atmosphere of constant change. The industry has not been able to settle down to its own affairs, to organise itself or to be able to plan ahead and develop itself in any kind of comprehensive way. Yet this is the very industry that depends so much upon long term planning. For instance, it requires a seven-year period for a vine after being first planted in the ground to grow, become mature and start producing grapes. All the planning that has to go on in that period indeed takes a great deal of investment faith and experience in dealing with the growing of grapes. It is that kind of activity which this Government fails to recognise and which obviously, through its constant actions of the last three years, continues to jeopardise the future of the industry. What this industry needs above all is stability.

SPEECH.PARA: The regional nature of the problem, particularly in South Australia along the River Murray, is how one gets stability into a policy which is administered by both State and Federal governments. The reason why the Liberal and National parties have established a wine study group is so that they can bring together the policy elements of both State and Federal government areas to ensure that a comprehensive policy can be developed for the Liberal and National parties in government. This will enable them to implement such a policy for the benefit of the industry. This is what the industry needs. While dealing with a matter such as a wine tax is very important, it is only an element of the total problem that is faced by the wine industry, the grape growers and the regional areas of South Australia that are involved in this problem. That is why we on this side of the chamber, excluding the Democrats, say that a policy is needed. We are determined to establish it so that we can develop a comprehensive and consistent theme for the industry to follow in the future.

We intend to consult widely with all community groups in regional areas, with industry leaders and with those who are deeply involved in the marketing of wine. We know that the wine industry has a lot to offer by establishing better techniques for the marketing of its products both domestically and overseas. Rather than spend $8m as this Government is doing on pulling vines out of the Clare Valley and the Riverland area, piling them into heaps and burning them, we would prefer to see money spent in other directions such as the promotion and development of markets overseas. Apparently, neither the Government nor the Democrats are capable of getting together that kind of progressive thinking.

One of the very serious problems that has arisen with the wine industry has been the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and the entertainment tax. Informed people in the wine industry make it quite clear that the biggest single factor causing the industry to decline since 1984, when this Government first introduced the wine tax, was the abolition of entertainment expenses for taxation purposes last October.

These amendments all relate to one area, namely, the 20 per cent sales tax on computer software. We have already made clear our reasons for moving these amendments. We have in this country a flourishing software industry. It is a growth industry of some magnitude. A sudden 20 per cent tax on this industry would have a devastating effect on it. We have also pointed out that the 20 per cent sales tax can be circumvented by various devices such as telephonic communication, and particularly by multinational companies through a variety of mechanisms. For all those reasons we are very strongly opposed to the imposition of a 20 per cent sales tax on computer software.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I declare an interest in this matter. A member of my family is an Australian who has devised a software program, a word processing program called Word Magic. It is already being exported to New Zealand and there is a prospect of it being exported to other parts of the world. With this amending legislation the Government is proposing to ensure that people in Australia who do anything of value immediately are militated against. As I understand it-I would be glad if the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) will elucidate this-this is a tax on the intellectual content of software. As with many other people who have been part of this type of operation and who do not have very much money, this member of my family has licensed the program to a software manufacturer who will manufacture it from this month and market it.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand the Bill, the deviser of the program, in this case the member of my family, will have to pay initially a 20 per cent tax on whatever royalties he gets from that company and income tax thereafter. I would be obliged if the Minister will tell me if I am wrong on this as a number of people in the software industry have told me that this is the case. If it is not the case there will be great relief throughout the community. This Government-the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) and the Minister for Finance-says that Australian industry has to get off its backside and that the Australian people have to innovate, they have to do things, they have to be creative, they have to export. Yet when they do so the Government says that it will impose a 20 per cent tax on them at the first instance. I cannot really believe that this is the case, that we have such a topsy-turvy, Alice in Wonderland situation with this Labor Government. It said when it came to power in 1983 that it would try to do something reasonable and innovative to get this country back onto a creative, outward looking road. So it became an exporter, it did something of value. But now the Government is saying to somebody who is creative, who is inventive, that he will be hit immediately with a 20 per cent tax and then pay income tax thereafter.

I wonder where this tax will go. Will it go to every area of innovation in the country? Will the Government say to an inventor, a writer, a musician, or a playwright that eventually he will be taxed on what it calls the intellectual content of what he does? How long does the Government think people will go on bothering to innovate, to take any notice of what Barry Jones and the Prime Minister say-that we have to get this country off the ground, that we have suddenly to become an exporter, that we have to become good, that in a high technology society we have to become excellent-if the Government undercuts in this way? What is there in it? There is not a great deal of money. It is just another case of the Government yet again knocking people who might be of some value.

The Labor Government in my mind is a self-destructive mechanism. It has reached the stage where possibly it has been in government long enough. Is it destroying itself internally. I do not care much about that, but it is beginning to destroy this society and its economic base at the important point, which is the point of innovation. All of us know, and the people in this Government have said it many times, that that is what we have to do. We have to get ourselves up by our boot straps. When we do that, what happens? The Government immediately attacks. I would be most grateful for the Minister's response to that specific point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Mason said, software is an intangible, intellectual property, protected not by patents but by copyright. The sales tax we currently have is levied on the hardware, on the device on which the software is stored, not on the software or intellectual property itself. This amendment to the sales tax laws tries to apply sales tax to the intellectual part of that combination, but the tax will apply only if the software is written on some type of storage medium. That is the subject of an enormous possible rort in the system. Software which is transmitted directly from computer to computer or through the air waves will not be taxable. Already the legislation is outdated in its concept because many micro-computer owners are buying software through bulletin boards, by having it directly delivered to them into their computers through modems, the telephone system or other means of direct communication.

SPEECH.PARA: The other area where the Government seems to be very much at sea is in what it thinks is software manufacture. As far as I can see in the Bill, software manufacture is deemed to be the act of copying the software material from one medium to another. Is not that great? The Government seems to ignore completely the process of programming and assembling software. Maybe the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) could tell me whether the assembling, the programming of software, is a research and development activity which will always be subject to the 150 per cent taxation allowance. That would certainly be a boost to the industry.

The Bill will destroy the fledgling Australian software industry because it is totally biased towards large international multi-national companies which have obtained a number of concessions under the Bill. A master tape which is imported containing software will be exempt from the wholesale tax. That is the main component which costs the money. Under the Government's definition it will be an input to manufacture. The tax will be levied only on copies made from that sale. The development of software is not deemed to be manufacture and therefore software purchased for modification which brings jobs into Australia-which the Government claims it wants to do-is not exempt. Hence we are taxing jobs in Australia and encouraging people to produce software overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is selling out to foreign interests again.
—Exactly, as Senator Mason says. I do not know who the Government is working for, but it is certainly not the Australian people.
—Where is the money going? Whose pocket is it going into?

—Indeed. Computer equipment which is purchased for software development is not tax exempt under the Government's proposal. However, computer equipment which is bought for copying software which has been produced overseas and which can be done automatically without employing Australian labour is tax exempt. This tax is directed at killing the software industry in Australia. Already an extra burden has been imposed by our distances and market-places in Australia. Software developed in Australia and delivered on hardware mediums such as tapes to which licensed rights for use are sold will be liable to sales tax.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the main ways in which contract programmers develop their programs is by doing a job for a particular Australian company and then taking the product and developing it further for sale as a general package. Those are the very people who form the core of the Australian software industry. They are the people who will be knocked by this process, especially if they want to retain title to that intellectual property, the software. If, however, the software is sold or deemed to be owned by the person for whom they produced it, the individual firm for which they produced it, it will be free from tax. So there will be no encouragement for people to develop a piece of software which works adequately in industry, in commerce and in an Australian environment and to take that software and use it in other places. This is exactly the opposite of what is needed to boost industry within this country.

Packaged software is always developed in conjunction with an initial purchaser because there is no other way of debugging it properly, of getting it to work properly. It is always the case if the vendor is to make any money out of it, that he must retain the copyright and ownership of the product. Under this law such development software will attract sales tax, an enormous extra burden of 20 per cent on our local industry. To summarise, I hope that the Minister can disillusion me about this matter and show me that I am wrong. I hope so for the sake of Australian industry, but I do not believe that he can.

I believe that the impact of this tax will fall specifically on local products in a completely unjust way and will lead to increased costs of development of software locally. It may also lead to the transfer of ownership rights from the developer who can profitably develop the package for Australia by sale and for eventual development of an export product once it has been tried on our local markets, to a purchaser who is in another business altogether and who will never develop that software any further. So we will lose a lot of great intellectual property. The incentive to buy-in packages and modify them under contract, to have them tailor-made for the purchaser, will mean that we will be handing over that industry to the larger operators, the IBMs of this world. That is exactly what the Government is doing. It is handing over our industry on a plate to the large multi-national companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like they did with the foreign banks.

—Exactly. It has done it to our banking industry. It has done it to our mining industry. It has done so in many areas. If the Government is keen on its buy Australian program it should also be encouraging Australian companies to produce here. This legislation is doing exactly the opposite. Currently, novel packaging techniques which by-pass the physical medium by the direct delivery of software will be encouraged but they will be available only to the large companies which have the money to do so. The small Aussie battler will be hit. That is what the Government is doing. We will end up with a run down of the Australian software development industry and an increased reliance on imported software. We will become a colony in an area where Australia has been establishing a reasonable reputation. That is what the Government will achieve. I think it should be damnably ashamed of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is reasonable to ask whether it is deliberate Government policy to kill off the smaller end of the Australian software industry when one considers this tax. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Incident at Returned Services League Hall, Brisbane-Legal Aid: Allen Douglas Thompson Case

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise with the Government an issue of which I think a lot of people in Australia are aware. I refer to an event that occurred on the evening of 27 September in the Returned Services League hall at Rosalie in Brisbane. The television channels carried shots of what could only be called a riot that occurred at an Aboriginal dinner dance. They carried pictures that I think no one would ever believe they would see in this country. I am quite sure that all Australians would hope that they would never see such pictures again. Contrary to some Press speculation about comments I have made to date, I do not raise this issue tonight to seek to place blame on either the Aboriginal people or the police. My interest is in trying to make sure that such events do not occur ever again in Australia. Quite frankly, I think that that view is shared not only by the Aboriginal people but also by the vast bulk of the police force in my own State.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to read to the Senate a letter that was written by a person who was at the dance that evening. I was not there and hence I am not in a position to be able to say what occurred, but I think this letter gives a very clear description. I believe that honourable senators will be able to judge for themselves the veracity of the letter because what is written and the concern that is expressed so obviously ring true. The letter states:

This is my letter of complaint about the atrocious behaviour of the Queensland Police towards us Aboriginals at an end of season football dance on the 27th September, 1986. The dance was held at the Ithaca R.S.L. sub-branch in Nash Street, Rosalie.

This is an account of what happened as I saw it. My husband and I were standing within the grounds of the R.S.L. with a friend and several other people. We had just come out of the R.S.L. building for some fresh air. The time was approximately 11.15 p.m. The police arrived on the premises, there were six at that time, they demanded to see the liquor licence, the licence was produced by the Brisbane Natives Rugby League committee member, Mrs Edith Mickelo. The police then left the premises, but, only to return five minutes later with reinforcements. There were plain clothes men, uniformed men and one woman, and dogs.
The time was approximately 11.20 p.m., about twelve policemen raced around the other side of the building with batons in hands and their dogs. They entered the building through a side door.

Approximately two to three minutes later, the police had left the building and regrouped on the road opposite the R.S.L. They waited it seemed another couple of minutes, then twenty policemen armed with batons in hands and dogs stormed the building. They were yelling obscenities at us as they raced past. They pushed, and shoved and pulled people as they went into the building with the guns unclipped in their holsters.

The dogs were barking at our people, we were all shocked and stunned because we did not know what the police were doing there. I did not see what happended inside the hall, but I heard someone call for reinforcements. Very quickly ten more policemen rushed into the building, they were uttering obscenities like-
a range of obsenities is listed-
as they charged the building. This time the police, about four of them, dragged a young girl down the stairs, knocking over other women and children as they went to put the girl into the paddy-wagon.

When the police were coming out of the building, I saw an old lady, aged between the fifty and sixty, pushed down the stairs, when she fell at the bottom of the stairs, a policeman hit her across the head with his baton.

Then, when all of the police were out of the building, I saw a uniformed policeman let his dog loose onto an Aboriginal man and woman who were just walking along the footpath. The Aboriginal couple jumped up onto the bonnet of a car for protection from the dogs, then, a couple of policemen dragged the man off the car and slung him to the ground and bashed him mercilessly with riot batons.
The police waited around in the yard and on the street another few minutes, then most of them stormed the building again. This action was uncalled for and they were unprovoked.

My husband, who was standing beside me, said `Why don't you go and solve some murders, pick up some rapists and drug pushers, instead of picking on us poor blacks! A policeman grabbed my husband from behind and and said `Right you're under arrest!' I said `Why are you taking him?' The policeman replied `Because I said so!' Then he and another two or three policemen armed with batons, took my husband and put him into the paddy-wagon.

Some of the police raced up the stairs again, indiscriminately hitting people with batons. We did not know and could not understand why they were harassing us. They arrested several other people, there were women and children screaming, and dogs barking at us. We were all scared and confused. The police did not seem to care what they did to us; they were verbally abusing us the whole time. And reinforcements were arriving all the time. The police were inciting a riot against us.

At that stage my friend and I walked away from the yard because the police were hounding us. We tried in vain to get a taxi, taxis could not get through anyway because the streets were cordoned off by police. The last incident I saw was a group of our young people, twenty in all, most were children, huddled together screaming on the footpath. They looked really scared. They just stood still because the police let their dogs loose on them.

Many of our men folk were arrested by this point in time, that is why our women and children retaliated by throwing bottles and empty cans. After this incident the police set their dogs on all the people who were still in the yard, they stormed the building again and were chasing our people in all directions. They swarmed upon our people who were still in the yard. The police created havoc.

I feared for my life and for the other people there who were being harassed and intimidated. The whole terrible ordeal was like a scene one sees on television that happens in South Africa. I was really very shaken up, I sincerely believed then that the police were going to start firing their guns at us. Thank God they did not resort to that because there were about seventy to eighty police personnel on the scene.

The situation was so incredible, because the entire nasty incident was created by belligerent police who appeared very psyched up for aggression against us. It seemed that the police came specifically to antagonise and intimidate us. The nightmare of police brutality was horrific, it was a traumatic experience for me and one I shall never, never forget.

As I said, I was not seeking and I am not seeking to work out who is to blame for the incident that occurred. Some 60-odd people were arrested and there will be a whole range of court cases that will, hopefully, in justice, sort out who is to blame.

My interest in raising the matter is because of the moral, legal and constitutional responsibility that is held by the Commonwealth Government regarding Aboriginal affairs in Australia. I believe that such an issue is not one for a State government, because it is not an issue which people in any other country will see as a State issue. They will see it as an Australian issue. I believe that it should be seen as an Australian issue. It is one that I think warrants an inquiry and one which needs an inquiry. As I said at the beginning of my speech, I do not believe that the majority of police in Queensland, the majority of Aboriginals or anyone who has viewed the television pictures of that incident want to see such an event ever occurring again in Australia. When one saw the events, one could not but be reminded of the scenes that we have seen from South Africa. It is not Australia that we saw on those television cameras. It does not reflect the types of views that people in Australia hold.

The Queensland authorities have already indicated that they have no intention of holding an inquiry. I think that that is the case. However, the people of Australia have handed the responsibility of Aboriginal affairs to the Commonwealth Government. I believe that this is a matter for the Commonwealth Government. It is a matter for our nation to ensure that such events do not occur again in Australia. I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), who is at the table tonight, to seek from the Government an assurance that it will have an inquiry into the matter to ensure that Australia's name now and into the future can, on such matters, always be the name of a nation that will not allow such elements and events to go uninvestigated and that it will not allow such events to occur in Australia again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), who is at the table tonight, to refer to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) a matter that I shall go into in some detail. It relates to legal aid in a case before the High Court of Australia. I think that at the moment legal aid resources are fairly short. I question whether they are being spent in the best possible manner in the case to which I refer. It relates to a man called Allen Douglas Thompson who has been convicted for six separate murders. He was convicted in 1984 for murders in Richardson of Ms Radmila Milosevic, her de facto husband, Mr Tony Baker, and their two young children. Subsequently, he was charged with the murder of two other Milosevic sisters, two murders which were alleged to have occurred in 1981 when a car crashed on the Monaro Highway. It was subsequent to the first convictions that he was then charged with those murders and was convicted for those murders.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Thompson appealed to the Federal Court which rejected the appeal against his convictions for offences alleged to have occurred on the Monaro Highway. Apparently, he has now appealed to the High Court. There is no suggestion, in the article that reports all this in the Canberra Times last Saturday, that it had anything to do with guilt or innocence. It is all to do with the border issue as to whether or not the two girls murdered in the motor vehicle were murdered in the Australian Capital Territory or New South Wales. Many people would say: `Who cares?'. I am a lawyer, but I am inclined to say that also.

The case is written up as an interesting legal issue. I have no doubt that it is. However, the article says that Thompson is appealing through his representatives, the Australian Capital Territory Legal Aid Office. It is not a question of a life sentence for murder; it is merely a question of whether the murders occurred in the Australian Capital Territory or a few yards away in New South Wales. I question whether legal aid funds are properly used for that purpose, even if it is a very important and highly significant legal issue. Perhaps there has been a special grant for this purpose to enable the case to go forward. However, I think that it is a matter that the Attorney-General should look at in terms of the guidelines for legal aid, where the money goes, and whether it is being well spent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had intended to ask a question tomorrow on the matter raised by Senator Macklin, but I think that it is relevant for me to give support at this stage to the matter raised. I do not think that the Senate can ignore what occurred in Brisbane. I believe that the Senate should support the proposition that there ought to be an inquiry. It is a Commonwealth responsibility. It is the responsibility of this Parliament to see that the Government carries out some investigation of the rather horrific incident that took place.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very difficult for us to take the stand that we do on South Africa and on apartheid when what occurred in Brisbane is exactly what is occurring in South Africa. Those of us who saw the television broadcasts were appalled by the action of one plain clothes policeman who used a baton repeatedly on a person and, having forced that person to the ground, proceeded to kick that person at length. That is only one incident of a number of incidents which occurred in the night. I do not think that we can ignore the call by Senator Macklin for an inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which night was this?

—The twenty-seventh. I think that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) should take up the matter with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) and search out what response the Government intends to take to make certain that this sort of activity by the police authorities, whether in Queensland or Western Australia, but in this particular case in Queensland, should continue.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that in Queensland we have lost the ability to be outraged by the behaviour of both government and citizens, in particular of the police. Since that sense of outrage seems to have been lost in Queensland, surely it is not lost nationally. I return to my first position. Senator Macklin's appeal for an inquiry should be strongly supported by the Senate and the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contribution to the adjournment debate. I will see that Senator Reid's request is addressed by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). I do not quite know what his scope to do things is in that respect. That is only an observation and I shall certainly seek his advice.

SPEECH.PARA: I did not hear all the circumstances as outlined by Senator Macklin. I shall certainly take steps to refer his request to the appropriate Minister very quickly. I appreciate very much what Senator Macklin and Senator Georges said about the matter. I think that it should be so referred and I shall see that that is done. I am not quite sure who the appropriate Minister is. Clearly, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) has to be involved. However, the Attorney-General may also be interested in the matter.
