PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 12 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What criteria are used for determining funds for university centres of excellence.
(2) How is selection determined when a new department is competing with an established department.
(3) Is the selection panel influenced by the success of a given department to meet (a) student need; (b) research need; and (c) community need.
(4) What is the future of this program to encourage innovation and excellence in tertiary education.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Although the honourable senator's question mentioned only Special Research Centres formerly known as Centres of Excellence, the information provided below relates also to Key Centres of Teaching and Research which this Government established to enhance teaching and research effort in both the university and advanced education sectors.

(1) & (2) The level of funds available for both Special Research Centres and Key Centres of Teaching and Research is determined on a triennial basis. For the 1985-87 triennium, over $16m is being provided for Special Research Centres and over $3m for Key Centres. Funds are made available to individual Special Research Centres to meet the costs of the necessary salaries, equipment and support services associated with the required higher level of research activity. Individual Key Centres receive an equal share of available funds directed towards the concentration of teaching and research effort by covering the costs of such items as the transfer of students and staff between higher education institutions, the purchase of equipment and library materials and the payment of contract academic and support staff.

Both Special Research Centres and Key Centres were selected on the basis of merit after calling for applications for grants. In the case of Special Research Centres, assessments were made in terms of leadership qualities, business management, the applicant's development potential, the adequacy of present university support, and the relevance of the intended work to national research interests; expert advice was sought from a wide range of Australian and overseas sources to assist the selection process. In selecting the Key Centres, attention was given to the capacity of applicants to develop a high standard of concentrated teaching and research activity, especially in areas of national need; particular emphasis was given to undergraduate work and to the promotion of links between higher education and the private sector. Institutional ranking, State priorities and the need for a balanced distribution among States, sectors and disciplines were also taken into account, along with advice from various bodies with expertise in the fields concerned.

(3) Under both programs, selection was influenced to varying extents, by the ability of applicants to meet student, research and community needs. While student need was not a major influence in determining the selection of Special Research Centres, an important outcome of this program has been the provision of enhanced research training opportunities for post-graduate students.

(4) Special Research Centres and Key Centres were established for the purpose of improving standards in higher education and their progress in this direction was to be reviewed after a suitable period of time. The Government will have an opportunity to assess their achievements when it receives advice on the future of both programs from the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission in the context of planning for the 1988-90 triennium.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 March 1986 (Hansard, page 1122), Senator Peter Baume asked me a question without notice in part about reports that more than 33,000 people, including 477 working apprentices, had been turned away from technical and further education courses this year in New South Wales. After receiving advice from the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission I am able to respond to that part of his question:

ANSWER.PARA: CTEC has confirmed that, on the basis of information which was current in the middle of March 1986, the number of unsuccessful applications for TAFE courses in NSW was of the order of 33,000 including some 2,000 applications for Stream 6 (personal enrichment courses). While these raw figures are correct I understand that they represent an over-estimate of the actual number of individuals who cannot gain entry to a course. The figures are derived from course standby lists from each college. These lists record the names of students who have applied for courses (and, where appropriate, are qualified to enter the course) but for whom a place is not available. Double counting occurs where individuals apply for more than one course at a college and/or for courses at a number of colleges. The figure of 33,000 unsuccessful applications thus exceeds by an unknown margin the number of persons who were unsuccessful seeking entry to TAFE courses in NSW early this year. It is likely that some of these persons will be successful later in the year.

The Commission has also confirmed that the number of unsuccessful applications did include 477 from apprentices in work. More recent information, however, indicates that 435 of the apprentices concerned were enrolled in the second semester.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
